description: Have you wanted to see what this programming thing is all about? Do you have issues figuring out where to start? Well, this course will show you how to get things set up and start with the basics of programming using the Python programming language. If you want to set up your machine, understand the basics of Python, and start understanding the basic tenets of programming, then please join us!

There it is.

00:23:29.770 --> 00:23:30.300
It's fine.

So let's take a look at

these last three.

if I hit this, all it's gonna do

00:24:31.510 --> 00:24:36.460
By default, it's going to expect that

00:24:36.460 --> 00:24:38.340
and all of these things

00:24:39.370 --> 00:24:42.870
And then from there,
let's say I open a folder, and

00:24:42.870 --> 00:24:45.530

So Open, and

When you open a folder in

So localized is actually on my desktop,

00:25:35.250 --> 00:25:40.075
So if I wanted to create a new file,

So you can start typing,

00:25:52.610 --> 00:25:56.784
That's good, and then correspondingly,

00:26:01.535 --> 00:26:04.905
important_project.

00:26:06.100 --> 00:26:10.970
And now I have a drop down, and I can take

00:26:10.970 --> 00:26:13.430
And it says, do you wanna move it, yep.

00:26:13.430 --> 00:26:19.540
And I have the ability to kind of just

454
00:26:19.540 --> 00:26:22.261
>> You don't have to close

455
00:26:22.261 --> 00:26:25.801
Yeah, cuz sometimes when you're doing

if you don't close a document first, it

Well, I'm gonna close this,

So it sees that it just moved

if you move it otherwise,

>> Like if you move this out to your
documents or something, or did,

00:27:02.128 --> 00:27:06.890
Because, I mean, cuz this is like

00:27:06.890 --> 00:27:11.487
You said, be in the desktop, and this

And then anything inside of it's like,

this is all contained

And does it even give you

if you wanna move it, you would have

And if you do do that, then you'll get

It'll disappear from this folder, and

00:27:38.810 --> 00:27:40.340
That means this has not been saved.

Effectively, it will keep open a version,

And then if you go to close it,

IF you hit Yes,

it'll re-save a new version in

So keep that in mind,

I'm actually gonna close this and

>> Yeah and I think I'm just,

I don't move locations of files

Or doing a file save as specifically and

cuz it just gets a little confusing to me.

>> It can get confusing, I will tell you,

But I know about these edge cases,

Make sure files are closed

That also includes the folder that

If we come in and

Notice that folder's over there, and

All right, so we know a little

Python is the old version which is

Python3 --version,
you gotta spell version right,

version, Python 3.6.5.

Windows users, you're probably going

And then, if worst comes to worst,

And there are some documentations

00:29:53.527 --> 00:29:58.831
Also, a beginner's guide that will

00:29:58.831 --> 00:30:03.400
taking you to places,
where to solve common errors.

So check those out, but for the most part,

00:30:07.621 --> 00:30:11.178
it's good to go, and, well,

00:30:11.178 --> 00:30:14.299
We have our editor,
we have Python 3.6.5, and, well,

00:30:14.299 --> 00:30:16.530
I guess we actually get

00:30:16.530 --> 00:30:19.052
But we're out of time for this episode,

>> All right, well, Justin,

Some really good foundational

00:30:24.180 --> 00:30:27.378
Because if we don't have it installed

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore the Read, Evaluate, Print, Loop (REPL) tool that is available with Python. Justin demonstrates and talks through some of the more common errors that people will encounter when first getting started.
episodes.title: Exploring the REPL
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.780 --> 00:00:02.978
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:13.188 --> 00:00:17.308
Hello, everyone and welcome back to
another exciting edition of DevProTV.

3
00:00:17.308 --> 00:00:18.665
I'm your host, Vonne Smith, and

4
00:00:18.665 --> 00:00:21.725
we are moving through our
applied fundamental series.

5
00:00:21.725 --> 00:00:24.215
In this episode,
we're going to be exploring the REPL.

6
00:00:24.215 --> 00:00:25.795
And here to help us is Mr.

7
00:00:25.795 --> 00:00:28.755
Justin Dennison, how are you?
>> I'm doing fantastic Vonne,

8
00:00:28.755 --> 00:00:30.585
how are you?
>> I'm doing pretty good.

9
00:00:30.585 --> 00:00:34.035
I'm feeling pretty confident about
that we've installed Python.

10
00:00:34.035 --> 00:00:38.340
And we're gonna use our text editor and
now you've thrown in this REPL.

11
00:00:38.340 --> 00:00:39.540
You said something about it,

12
00:00:39.540 --> 00:00:43.760
but what exactly is the REPL?
>> Well,

13
00:00:43.760 --> 00:00:48.930
this is one of those things that as we're
coming back to these fundamental concepts,

14
00:00:48.930 --> 00:00:54.250
I've kind of been deep in it for a while,
I'll throw around terminology and luckily

15
00:00:54.250 --> 00:00:58.988
I've got Vonne over here to keep me honest
>> The REPL R-E-P-L right,

16
00:00:58.988 --> 00:01:04.738
you saw that on the lower third
as we came into this episode,

17
00:01:04.738 --> 00:01:09.460
and that means Read Evaluate Print Loop,
okay?

18
00:01:09.460 --> 00:01:13.230
So those are actually just four words,
you're like Justin you just said words,

19
00:01:13.230 --> 00:01:15.820
I don't know what that actually means.

20
00:01:15.820 --> 00:01:19.910
Essentially what a REPL does is
it takes user input, you right?

21
00:01:19.910 --> 00:01:22.000
It reads it from you.

22
00:01:22.000 --> 00:01:23.985
It takes whatever you put in there and
evaluates it.

23
00:01:23.985 --> 00:01:26.130
What does that mean by evaluate?

24
00:01:26.130 --> 00:01:28.910
Well if I say, hey what's three plus two,
you go it's five.

25
00:01:28.910 --> 00:01:31.970
Well, you evaluated that thing and

26
00:01:31.970 --> 00:01:35.430
then it prints it when you set it
back to me, that's like printing it.

27
00:01:35.430 --> 00:01:39.250
And then it comes back around and
looks for the next input,

28
00:01:39.250 --> 00:01:41.110
so that's where the loop comes, right.

29
00:01:41.110 --> 00:01:45.600
So it'll say, what do you got, I type
it in, it reads it in, it evaluates it,

30
00:01:45.600 --> 00:01:49.740
it spits out the result, and
then it asks for the next thing, okay?

31
00:01:49.740 --> 00:01:53.590
What's next, what's next, what's next.
>> And I almost, I feel like I used some

32
00:01:53.590 --> 00:01:56.595
terminology that I wasn't really
sure I was using in the right place.

33
00:01:56.595 --> 00:01:58.860
[INAUDIBLE] meant a compiler?

34
00:02:00.150 --> 00:02:02.010
Is that the same or
is that completely different?

35
00:02:02.010 --> 00:02:03.380
>> No, so during this time,

36
00:02:03.380 --> 00:02:06.015
Python was being interpreted on the fly.

37
00:02:06.015 --> 00:02:09.410
So it gets a little hazy
sometimes with new languages,

38
00:02:09.410 --> 00:02:14.090
because really Python sometimes compiled,

39
00:02:14.090 --> 00:02:17.490
depending on the implementation or
it's compiled while it's running.

40
00:02:17.490 --> 00:02:20.420
But during the REPL, you can think
of it as it being interpreted.

41
00:02:20.420 --> 00:02:24.358
I give it something and at that moment,
it doesn't change into anything.

42
00:02:24.358 --> 00:02:26.510
It just says, cool,
I know how to evaluate that, so

43
00:02:26.510 --> 00:02:29.630
it interprets the respective meaning,
right?

44
00:02:29.630 --> 00:02:34.040
So as I said, three plus two, that's five.

45
00:02:34.040 --> 00:02:37.640
We are interpreting three
plus two as you want me to

46
00:02:37.640 --> 00:02:39.550
put those two things together and
spit that back out.

47
00:02:39.550 --> 00:02:44.210
So it does get a little shaky there
before our intents and purposes.

48
00:02:44.210 --> 00:02:47.750
We're gonna say that Python isn't
an interpreted language and

49
00:02:47.750 --> 00:02:50.780
we'll always kind of interpret
what is written out and

50
00:02:50.780 --> 00:02:54.034
kinda bring it back to us.
>> And those other languages, I'm

51
00:02:54.034 --> 00:02:58.224
kinda now I'm stuck on I'm like I don't
even know what a compiler is anymore.

52
00:02:58.224 --> 00:03:00.850
[LAUGH]
>> So there are other languages and one

53
00:03:00.850 --> 00:03:06.430
could say that compilation is sometimes
used in kind of an ambiguous way.

54
00:03:06.430 --> 00:03:07.680
But for the most part,

55
00:03:07.680 --> 00:03:10.640
compiler languages would be languages
where I have something, right?

56
00:03:10.640 --> 00:03:15.330
Typically text based code, and
it is compiled to machine level code for

57
00:03:15.330 --> 00:03:18.440
a particular platform,
effectively it turns into ones and

58
00:03:18.440 --> 00:03:20.250
zeroes types of instructions.

59
00:03:20.250 --> 00:03:24.522
I'm over simplifying that a great deal,
but then that thing is what's run.

60
00:03:24.522 --> 00:03:28.842
So your machine knows how to run
that thing, whereas in Python,

61
00:03:28.842 --> 00:03:31.562
I can just feed it
a little bit at a time and

62
00:03:31.562 --> 00:03:36.060
it goes cool I know how to run any
of these as long as they're valid.

63
00:03:36.060 --> 00:03:38.700
So it interprets it as it goes, and

64
00:03:38.700 --> 00:03:41.720
then usually there's something underneath
that knows how to interpret that.

65
00:03:41.720 --> 00:03:44.990
That it abstracts away from your
respective computer, that's why you

66
00:03:44.990 --> 00:03:48.974
can install it on Linux and Mac and-
>> PCs.

67
00:03:48.974 --> 00:03:53.290
[LAUGH]
>> Windows, wow, I almost forgot there.

68
00:03:53.290 --> 00:03:56.310
And you have a very similar experience,
and you have a REPL.

69
00:03:57.340 --> 00:04:01.220
A REPL is a little more difficult
when it is a compiled language.

70
00:04:01.220 --> 00:04:06.210
Not impossible, but
a read-evaluate-print-loop capability

71
00:04:06.210 --> 00:04:09.380
gets a little shaky when it's
a purely compiled language.

72
00:04:09.380 --> 00:04:11.980
>> Okay well, that helps me know what I

73
00:04:11.980 --> 00:04:16.980
was trying to say that really didn't
know what I was trying to say.

74
00:04:16.980 --> 00:04:18.568
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] And that's to be expected,

75
00:04:18.568 --> 00:04:21.010
you will encounter terminology,
and jargon, and things, right.

76
00:04:22.200 --> 00:04:24.950
Vonne, you need to keep me honest,
if there's something you don't know and

77
00:04:24.950 --> 00:04:28.230
maybe it's because you haven't
been in a respective episode or

78
00:04:28.230 --> 00:04:31.170
whatever it is, you just say Justin,
what are you talking about.

79
00:04:31.170 --> 00:04:32.670
And I will try my best to answer it.

80
00:04:32.670 --> 00:04:38.170
All right, so we know what a REPL is
at a high level, but why do we care?

81
00:04:38.170 --> 00:04:39.550
Well, it's really easy.

82
00:04:39.550 --> 00:04:43.520
It's kind of like you're almost
a 20 questions kind of thing.

83
00:04:43.520 --> 00:04:45.320
You go, hey REPL, what's this?

84
00:04:45.320 --> 00:04:48.200
And it goes, all right, read that in,
I evaluate, there it is.

85
00:04:48.200 --> 00:04:49.142
All right, what's next?

86
00:04:49.142 --> 00:04:52.680
Right, so if you've ever played
20 questions, is it an animal?

87
00:04:52.680 --> 00:04:54.400
Is it a truck?

88
00:04:54.400 --> 00:04:57.237
Don't, that should not
be your second question.

89
00:04:57.237 --> 00:04:57.980
[LAUGH] Is it living?

90
00:04:57.980 --> 00:04:59.960
Is it dead?
Those type of things.

91
00:04:59.960 --> 00:05:04.600
Effectively, you're giving it things to
evaluate to see if they're valid, and

92
00:05:04.600 --> 00:05:08.500
what the result is all right, and
then it's gonna spit it back out to you.

93
00:05:09.590 --> 00:05:12.580
So that is perfectly okay, now

94
00:05:14.470 --> 00:05:18.840
how does this actually
work when we're using it?

95
00:05:18.840 --> 00:05:22.380
So if you take a look at the screen here,
we're actually gonna hop in to the REPL.

96
00:05:22.380 --> 00:05:25.560
And in the previous episode, we saw this

Cuz even though this is a number,
you're like, it's 23, it's 23, it's 23,

341
00:20:30.960 --> 00:20:32.310
that's fine.

342
00:20:32.310 --> 00:20:38.290
But what if it was a list of

343
00:20:38.290 --> 00:20:43.910
You go, well, I would rather just have a
cup that I can go, there they are, right?

344
00:20:43.910 --> 00:20:47.330
So you can think of it as what if I
had a whole bunch of marbles, and

345
00:20:47.330 --> 00:20:49.230
I wanna hold them in my hand.

346
00:20:49.230 --> 00:20:51.530
I go, well, there's that one marble,
there's that other marble.

347
00:20:51.530 --> 00:20:54.660
Or do you wanna cup that contains
all the marbles together?

348
00:20:54.660 --> 00:20:56.380
And you go there's all the marbles.

349
00:20:56.380 --> 00:21:00.060
And I can rifle through the cup,
and look for individual marbles.

350
00:21:00.060 --> 00:21:02.240
So it can get a little more complicated.

351
00:21:02.240 --> 00:21:06.520
But by and large, anytime you're thinking
about creating a variable, right,

352
00:21:06.520 --> 00:21:11.490
through assignment, through this operator,
and effectively you're creating this

353
00:21:11.490 --> 00:21:15.635
container, as Vonne said,
that can also dump out, right?

354
00:21:15.635 --> 00:21:21.050
Ooh, that root beer's bad, and
you get a different drink, right?

355
00:21:21.050 --> 00:21:22.523
It could be milk,
orange juice, I don't know.

356
00:21:22.523 --> 00:21:25.470
All of those in the same
cup might be weird.

357
00:21:25.470 --> 00:21:27.180
But the computer doesn't care.

358
00:21:27.180 --> 00:21:35.560
Now, there's one thing about about
labeling these cups that is very specific.

359
00:21:35.560 --> 00:21:37.000
Regardless of whether you're in Python or

360
00:21:37.000 --> 00:21:40.100

you should follow a set of rules.

361
00:21:40.100 --> 00:21:42.330
If it's a single word for

362
00:21:42.330 --> 00:21:47.600
a variable name, then you just write that
word in lowercase letters, all right?

363
00:21:47.600 --> 00:21:53.710
However, there are some exceptions.

364
00:21:55.863 --> 00:22:01.267
Can't start with, There's a start there.

365
00:22:03.229 --> 00:22:10.110
Can't start with like exclamation point,
period.

366
00:22:10.110 --> 00:22:12.370
It's not gonna have a quote in it.

367
00:22:12.370 --> 00:22:17.360
Like these kind of special characters, for
the most part, stay away away from those.

368
00:22:17.360 --> 00:22:22.800
The one that I do use and
is allowed is underscore, all right?

369
00:22:22.800 --> 00:22:24.580
And you'll see why.

370
00:22:24.580 --> 00:22:27.080
Now, can't start with those.

371
00:22:27.080 --> 00:22:31.560
For the most part it can't
contain these at all.

372
00:22:31.560 --> 00:22:36.694
It can't start with or contain,

373
00:22:38.748 --> 00:22:43.510
The period sometimes hops in there.
>> Because these are all

374
00:22:43.510 --> 00:22:48.010
characters that mean something,
like a slash is like a directory and

375
00:22:48.010 --> 00:22:49.690
the dot is just like a file extension.

376
00:22:49.690 --> 00:22:50.950
I'm just thinking in general terms.

377
00:22:50.950 --> 00:22:54.240
So you don't want to ever, that's
what we talked about like file names,

378
00:22:54.240 --> 00:22:55.470
any of these things.

379
00:22:55.470 --> 00:22:57.657
Worksheet names can't
even do that in Excel.

380
00:22:57.657 --> 00:23:02.130
It's just kind of an overall
generality of computers really.

381
00:23:02.130 --> 00:23:02.750
>> Yeah, and

382
00:23:02.750 --> 00:23:06.883
they all have their kind of requirements
and Python says, you know what?

383
00:23:06.883 --> 00:23:11.655
No exclamation points, no slashes in
the variable names, no dashes actually,

384
00:23:11.655 --> 00:23:12.860
no hyphens rather.

385
00:23:12.860 --> 00:23:14.600
You can't use those.

386
00:23:14.600 --> 00:23:17.860
The dot sometimes hops in there,
the period.

387
00:23:17.860 --> 00:23:20.230
It's not gonna be specific
to the variable name but

388
00:23:20.230 --> 00:23:23.490
you may see it with a variable name and
some other stuff later on.

389
00:23:23.490 --> 00:23:25.736
So that's why I'm like
[SOUND] it gets there.

390
00:23:25.736 --> 00:23:31.100
But in the actual variable name, I can't
use those to label my cup, all right?

391
00:23:31.100 --> 00:23:35.938
I can use an underscore, and

392
00:23:35.938 --> 00:23:43.359
I can use numbers, But
not at the beginning.

393
00:23:47.569 --> 00:23:50.484
Now the reason I can't use numbers
at the beginning is, well,

394
00:23:50.484 --> 00:23:53.670
it goes that's a number,
like the number seven.

395
00:23:53.670 --> 00:23:55.042
Has to be later on, so it goes, okay.

396
00:23:55.042 --> 00:23:56.943
And that's just how it reads.

397
00:23:56.943 --> 00:23:57.760
You can use numbers.

398
00:23:57.760 --> 00:23:59.526
You can use the underscore.

399
00:23:59.526 --> 00:24:01.271
So what are some examples?

400
00:24:03.528 --> 00:24:06.487
So let's go with the food example.

401
00:24:06.487 --> 00:24:08.078
So favorite food.

402
00:24:08.078 --> 00:24:14.450
So if I wanted to write favorite
food as a variable name, underscore,

403
00:24:14.450 --> 00:24:20.606
so each additional word,
the space is replaced by an underscore and

404
00:24:20.606 --> 00:24:25.176
you keep everything lower case.
>> I was just gonna ask that,

405
00:24:25.176 --> 00:24:29.717
I assumed but just making sure you can't
have spaces within a variable name.

406
00:24:29.717 --> 00:24:34.651
It's just not allowed, so the underscore
would be one way that you can replace

407
00:24:34.651 --> 00:24:37.372
it.
>> So, yes Vonne you replace spaces with

408
00:24:37.372 --> 00:24:40.998
underscores, and
that should be good for those spaces.

409
00:24:40.998 --> 00:24:46.165
But something to keep in mind is
notice I have lowercase letters here,

410
00:24:46.165 --> 00:24:49.635
right?
>> You could do lowercase favorite,

411
00:24:49.635 --> 00:24:54.953
uppercase food but
it's not that it's like it's not allowed.

412
00:24:54.953 --> 00:24:58.830
It's just not accepted by the community.

413
00:24:58.830 --> 00:25:01.601
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, you're absolutely correct.

414
00:25:01.601 --> 00:25:06.853
It is preferred in Python code that
you do when, this is, I think.

415
00:25:06.853 --> 00:25:09.377
If I'm not mistaken it's
called snake casing.

416
00:25:09.377 --> 00:25:12.206
So, lower case letters with hyphens
between them, or excuse me,

417
00:25:12.206 --> 00:25:14.890
with underscores between them,
not hyphens that'll break.

418
00:25:16.530 --> 00:25:20.392
There's another one called camel
casing which is exactly what you said.

419
00:25:20.392 --> 00:25:23.357
You will see some code written like
that especially in other languages,

420
00:25:23.357 --> 00:25:25.800
it would technically work,
it's just not conventional.

421
00:25:25.800 --> 00:25:28.510
So if you hand it off to other
people in the community,

422
00:25:28.510 --> 00:25:32.740
if I was looking at your code I would say,
you should probably follow conventions.

423
00:25:32.740 --> 00:25:37.380
If you don't follow conventions, then it
makes it harder for people to help you,

424
00:25:37.380 --> 00:25:39.341
when they're trying to help you.

425
00:25:39.341 --> 00:25:40.213
So, do that.

426
00:25:40.213 --> 00:25:43.580
Now, something to keep it mind.

427
00:25:43.580 --> 00:25:44.660
I said you can't use numbers.

428
00:25:44.660 --> 00:25:46.450
So this is my second favorite food.

429
00:25:46.450 --> 00:25:50.470
I can say, favorite_food2, perfectly okay.

430
00:25:50.470 --> 00:25:55.710
If I'm trying to do my
second favorite food, right?

431
00:25:55.710 --> 00:25:58.730
You wanted to, you can't do that

00:25:58.730 --> 00:26:00.870
have a number at the beginning of it.

433
00:26:00.870 --> 00:26:05.215
So you get to add on, you could add on

434
00:26:05.215 --> 00:26:09.310
You could go on and on and

435
00:26:09.310 --> 00:26:12.460
You have some disallowed characters
that they can't contain at all.

436
00:26:12.460 --> 00:26:15.317
You can use the underscore,
you can use numbers but

437
00:26:15.317 --> 00:26:17.989
you can't start a variable
name with a number.

438
00:26:17.989 --> 00:26:21.880
Your variables should be descriptive,
all right?

439
00:26:21.880 --> 00:26:26.790
Notice that favorite food, well
disregard the two and the other stuff,

440
00:26:26.790 --> 00:26:30.275
but favorite food, and you're like, I bet

00:26:30.275 --> 00:26:32.021
You should use that to your advantage.

00:26:32.021 --> 00:26:35.300
If you said ff, I'll be like.

00:26:36.350 --> 00:26:38.403

French fries,
maybe that is your favorite food.

00:26:40.820 --> 00:26:42.941
Maybe it means fast foray.

446
00:26:42.941 --> 00:26:44.800
It could mean a whole bunch of stuff.

447
00:26:44.800 --> 00:26:47.421
So use descriptive names.

448
00:26:47.421 --> 00:26:49.440
Don't go crazy, right?

449
00:26:49.440 --> 00:26:55.244
Don't write sentences upon sentences but
a few kind of spaced out.

450
00:26:55.244 --> 00:26:59.277
Underscore lowercase words that
describe what the variable

451
00:26:59.277 --> 00:27:02.379
actually contains.
>> Well like you said you wanna try to

452
00:27:02.379 --> 00:27:06.462
make it as easy as possible for yourself,
and for other people to understand it.

453
00:27:06.462 --> 00:27:11.155
Cuz basically it's almost like you're

00:27:11.155 --> 00:27:14.535
And so if you're using verbs and
nouns for lack of a better term,

455
00:27:14.535 --> 00:27:17.554
it's gonna make more sense
once you write it out in code.

456
00:27:17.554 --> 00:27:21.525
Otherwise just like the Fafo and
all that kind of things.

457
00:27:21.525 --> 00:27:24.330
That's not gonna make any sense.
>> Yeah, definitely don't do.

458
00:27:24.330 --> 00:27:27.576
It seems like an easy way to
get past things right now.

459
00:27:27.576 --> 00:27:31.035
Come a month later and you go xffd.

460
00:27:31.035 --> 00:27:32.874
I don't know what any of these mean.

461
00:27:32.874 --> 00:27:36.980
There are times where you can use single
variables, single letter variables.

462
00:27:36.980 --> 00:27:40.213
But if you're trying to write a readable,
acceptable program,

463
00:27:40.213 --> 00:27:43.818
your variable names work like this,
you're always gonna assign them.

464
00:27:43.818 --> 00:27:48.750
And as I said, there are some edge cases
that could crop up as we continue to

00:27:52.981 --> 00:27:56.433
Because right now without context
you'll just go, that sounds bad and

00:27:56.433 --> 00:27:58.000
then totally forget about them.

468
00:27:58.000 --> 00:27:59.297
So we'll go with that.

469
00:27:59.297 --> 00:28:03.885
But Vonne, I think we have a pretty
good grasp on variables contain data,

470

data has a type of data that's associated
with it, how to inspect that, and

00:28:08.621 --> 00:28:12.258
as well as some conventions
when we're using variables.

472
00:28:12.258 --> 00:28:16.841
So, we have a lot more coming at you but
for now I think I'm done.

473
00:28:16.841 --> 00:28:17.375
>> All right,

474
00:28:17.375 --> 00:28:20.910
well I'm feeling variably comfortable
with this on these variables, yeah.

475
00:28:20.910 --> 00:28:21.518
I know, I try.

476
00:28:21.518 --> 00:28:24.724
But actually, no that was a great
explanation about the foundations of

477
00:28:24.724 --> 00:28:28.584
variables, but like you said, edge-case
scenarios, we'll come around to that.

478
00:28:28.584 --> 00:28:34.109
But at least now, I feel pretty confident
in what this is, and gonna move forward.

479
00:28:34.109 --> 00:28:37.582
But for now, we're gonna go ahead and
wrap this one up.

480
00:28:37.582 --> 00:28:40.074
Singing off for DevProTV,

00:28:40.074 --> 00:28:40.859
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

482
00:28:40.859 --> 00:28:42.237
>> And we'll see you soon.

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne look at the difference between expressions and statements. Justin highlights some of the nuance details for considering if the Python code is a statement or an expression.
episodes.title: Expressions and Statements

Like what does it mean to be

00:02:49.073 --> 00:02:50.248

Okay, I feel like it's one of those things

you progress, and

An expression is a piece

84
00:04:32.517 --> 00:04:35.111

Person2, nope that's wrong.

440
00:24:45.920 --> 00:24:47.730
Let me clear this out.

441
00:24:47.730 --> 00:24:50.070
There we go, all right,
so what does it say?

442
00:24:50.070 --> 00:24:53.930
It says, well the name is Vonne,

443

the favorite number is 7,
likes cheese is true.

444
00:25:00.270 --> 00:25:02.598
So if you were to think of this
kind of like a book dictionary,

445
00:25:02.598 --> 00:25:08.240
you go favorite number 7, name

446
00:25:08.240 --> 00:25:12.360
Vonne, so
you look up what's called the key.

447
00:25:13.810 --> 00:25:18.940
And that's the respective value or
in a traditional dictionary sense,

448
00:25:18.940 --> 00:25:21.480
the word and the definition.

449
00:25:21.480 --> 00:25:22.710
So what is the name?

450
00:25:22.710 --> 00:25:26.230
It's Vonne, does that person like cheese?

451
00:25:26.230 --> 00:25:27.600
Yes, all right?

452
00:25:28.810 --> 00:25:32.770
This and this actually encapsulate
the exact same information.

453
00:25:34.550 --> 00:25:39.390
However, these have labels for
their respective entries and

455
00:25:42.580 --> 00:25:45.890
Now the whole goal was to give you an
overview to give you a C, but I can tell

456
00:25:45.890 --> 00:25:49.330
you by the look of Vonne's face that
you're like, I don't know why I would ever

use dictionaries, that's kind of weird.
>> It's a little, it's kind of,

458
00:25:53.440 --> 00:25:54.810
I don't know.

459
00:25:54.810 --> 00:26:00.730
There's a lot going on in there and
I wasn't expecting it to where you have to

460
00:26:00.730 --> 00:26:04.890
list the term or type in the term and
then give it its value.

461
00:26:04.890 --> 00:26:07.910
You're putting in,
I thought it had a little bit more

462
00:26:09.490 --> 00:26:14.850
internal magic but I think I'm again,
I have to remember this is a data type.

463
00:26:14.850 --> 00:26:20.040
It's not just like a functionality of
the language so that's where I'm stuck in.

464
00:26:20.040 --> 00:26:22.162
But yeah,
I'm still like why would you do this?

465
00:26:22.162 --> 00:26:23.650
>> And dictionary is you're like, man,

466
00:26:23.650 --> 00:26:25.770
I would never use this, those are bad.

467
00:26:25.770 --> 00:26:29.585
And then once you learn kinda
where they're applied and

468
00:26:29.585 --> 00:26:33.408
where they're used you go,
I see how those are used.

469
00:26:33.408 --> 00:26:36.830
So if you're feeling the same
way as Vonne don't worry, right?

470
00:26:36.830 --> 00:26:39.200
Dictionaries, you're like
there's a lot going on.

471
00:26:40.250 --> 00:26:43.100
We'll see the dictionaries
continue to crop up as we learn

472
00:26:43.100 --> 00:26:45.240
a little more about Python.

473
00:26:45.240 --> 00:26:48.740
If you so
want to indulge in learning a little more,

474
00:26:48.740 --> 00:26:51.900
sometimes these are like hash maps.

475
00:26:51.900 --> 00:26:55.280
This is technically like a hash map.

476
00:26:55.280 --> 00:26:57.750
It's a little extra, right?

477
00:26:57.750 --> 00:27:00.060
If you're like, I don't wanna look
that up, that's totally okay.

478
00:27:00.060 --> 00:27:01.340
We're gonna stick with dictionaries and

479
00:27:01.340 --> 00:27:03.818
from here on out that's
all I will ever call them.

480
00:27:03.818 --> 00:27:06.600
But it'll just take little
bit before those make sense

481
00:27:06.600 --> 00:27:08.020
as we learn a little more.
>> And

482
00:27:08.020 --> 00:27:10.150
just one last question on
this particular example.

483
00:27:10.150 --> 00:27:12.280
You did person2,
that's a different variable, but

484
00:27:12.280 --> 00:27:14.670
you used the same information just as

485
00:27:14.670 --> 00:27:19.670
an example of two different ways you
can basically do the same thing.

486
00:27:19.670 --> 00:27:24.240
That's the reason why you said person2.
>> That is exactly why and

487
00:27:24.240 --> 00:27:28.480
this was to illustrate
kind of this core idea.

488
00:27:28.480 --> 00:27:31.960
This is the exact same
representation of Vonne,

489
00:27:34.180 --> 00:27:38.210
presented using different types or ways.

490
00:27:38.210 --> 00:27:42.840
One is a dictionary,
one is a tuple, by doing that,

491
00:27:42.840 --> 00:27:45.260
we kind of get this trade off, right?

492
00:27:45.260 --> 00:27:48.400
When would I use a dictionary,
well if you need to do x, y, and

493
00:27:48.400 --> 00:27:51.260
z, dictionary is a good
way to represent Vonne.

494
00:27:51.260 --> 00:27:55.560
Well, what about if I just need a name,
a number and likes cheese,

495
00:27:55.560 --> 00:27:59.700
likes pickles and I know that it's always
gonna be and I don't, use a tuple.

496
00:27:59.700 --> 00:28:02.750
And then we'll talk about those
trade-offs and when you would pick one

497
00:28:02.750 --> 00:28:05.370
versus the other kinda as we move forward.
>> And

498
00:28:05.370 --> 00:28:08.610
the dictionary is more of like
you're adding the labels in there.

499
00:28:08.610 --> 00:28:10.650
The other one you're not adding
the labels and that's where,

500
00:28:10.650 --> 00:28:16.080
you're getting more information,
the expanded version of the information

501
00:28:16.080 --> 00:28:19.730
rather than just the condensed version.
>> You're exactly correct,

502
00:28:19.730 --> 00:28:24.280
and, ultimately, interestingly enough, as
we learn more we'll find out that we can

503
00:28:24.280 --> 00:28:27.680
actually take one and
kind of go back and forth to the other.

504
00:28:27.680 --> 00:28:30.580
So you're not stuck if
you pick the wrong one.

505
00:28:30.580 --> 00:28:34.232
But Vonne, I'm looking at the clock,
we're definitely out of time.

506
00:28:34.232 --> 00:28:36.739
We're gonna continue looking
a little more in depth for

507
00:28:36.739 --> 00:28:39.726
each of these data types as we move
forward through our fundamental

508
00:28:39.726 --> 00:28:40.611
series.
>> Yeah,

509
00:28:40.611 --> 00:28:45.270
I'm gonna take a bite of my own medicine,
or a scoop of my own medicine.

510
00:28:45.270 --> 00:28:49.850
A spoonful of my own medicine, and
say you know what, you got it.

511
00:28:49.850 --> 00:28:51.290
Stop, move on, and

512
00:28:51.290 --> 00:28:54.750
let's just keep on going down,
all of the things in our series.

513
00:28:54.750 --> 00:28:56.680
So thank you for that information.

514
00:28:56.680 --> 00:28:59.582
Thank you all for sticking around, and

For now, we're gonna wrap this one up.

Signing off for DevProTV,

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne dive further into using number types for data. Justin discusses the similarities and differences between integers and floats.
episodes.title: Basic Data Types: Numbers
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.118 --> 00:00:10.118
[MUSIC].

2
00:00:13.197 --> 00:00:17.190
Hello everyone, and welcome back to
another exciting edition of DevProTV.

3
00:00:17.190 --> 00:00:18.360
I'm your host, Vonne Smith, and

4
00:00:18.360 --> 00:00:21.100
we're moving through our
programming fundamentals series.

5
00:00:21.100 --> 00:00:24.900
And we are gonna look at data types
a little more, and specifically numbers.

6
00:00:24.900 --> 00:00:27.413
And here to help us is Mr.
Justin Dennison, how are you?

7
00:00:27.413 --> 00:00:28.937
>> I'm doing fantastic,
Vonne, how are you today?

8
00:00:28.937 --> 00:00:32.453
>> I'm doing pretty good,
data types, numbers,

9
00:00:32.453 --> 00:00:35.294
they're just numbers, right [LAUGH]?

10
00:00:35.294 --> 00:00:36.266
>> One would think, but

11
00:00:36.266 --> 00:00:39.520
I would like to make sure that we all
know like the behaviors of numbers.

12
00:00:39.520 --> 00:00:41.830
But there are some nuanced differences,
all right.

13
00:00:41.830 --> 00:00:46.570
So numbers in particular in Python and
some other programming languages

14
00:00:46.570 --> 00:00:48.550
are typically subdivided
by the types of numbers.

15
00:00:48.550 --> 00:00:52.385
This has to do with how they're
represented on the respective hardware.

16
00:00:52.385 --> 00:00:55.031
Integers, whole numbers,
right, positive and

17
00:00:55.031 --> 00:00:58.230
negative whole numbers
are represented one way.

18
00:00:58.230 --> 00:01:02.550
Whereas floating point or decimal numbers,
have to be careful there,

19
00:01:02.550 --> 00:01:04.050
they have a decimal place.

20
00:01:04.050 --> 00:01:07.950
Floating point numbers
are represented a different way.

21
00:01:07.950 --> 00:01:11.700
The respective behaviors are the same,
though, right?

22
00:01:11.700 --> 00:01:15.980
They have all these operations
that you can use with numbers.

23
00:01:15.980 --> 00:01:19.364
And, well,
you kinda get numbers back, right,

24
00:01:19.364 --> 00:01:23.808
when I say kinda, you get numbers back,
there's no kinda to it.

25
00:01:23.808 --> 00:01:28.296
So with that said, we have to be careful
because, well, this is an integer and

26
00:01:28.296 --> 00:01:31.504
then it actually ends up being
a floating point number.

27
00:01:31.504 --> 00:01:33.645
Or it's a floating point number and
ends up being an integer.

28
00:01:33.645 --> 00:01:39.681
There's some, weirdness we need to be
aware of when we're using actual numbers.

29
00:01:39.681 --> 00:01:44.661
All right, so integers, whole numbers,
floats, floating point numbers,

30
00:01:44.661 --> 00:01:50.420
they have a decimal place, they have
a fractional value, which could be zero.

31
00:01:50.420 --> 00:01:52.698
But let's go ahead and
take a look at the screen.

32
00:01:52.698 --> 00:01:55.080
We're still gonna be playing
around in the REPL a little bit.

33
00:01:55.080 --> 00:01:59.663
This is just a quick overview of all
of the operations that we can use.

34
00:01:59.663 --> 00:02:04.560
Well, a large amount of the operations
that we can use with respective numbers.

35
00:02:04.560 --> 00:02:07.616
All right, so
I'm gonna hop inside of the Python 3 REPL.

36
00:02:07.616 --> 00:02:11.498
I'm gonna clear this screen out, and

37
00:02:11.498 --> 00:02:16.954
I'm gonna say,
how about first = 1, second = 3,

38
00:02:16.954 --> 00:02:20.985
yeah, not 2, just go with me on that.

39
00:02:20.985 --> 00:02:26.595
And then third = 4.7, all right, so
we have two integers and a float.

40
00:02:26.595 --> 00:02:31.291
And we've seen this in previous episodes,
if we wanted to check that,

41
00:02:31.291 --> 00:02:34.990
we could do the following,
and there we go, all right?

42
00:02:34.990 --> 00:02:38.570
Now, let's take a look, and
we've seen this a little bit,

43
00:02:38.570 --> 00:02:43.580
and we can already do kind of
numeric operations, and we get a 4.

44
00:02:43.580 --> 00:02:47.322
Well, what is the type of first + second?

45
00:02:47.322 --> 00:02:51.080
It is an integer, okay, all right?

46
00:02:51.080 --> 00:02:53.360
Well, can we do first + third?

47
00:02:54.890 --> 00:02:59.501
Not if you put a random parenthesis
there that doesn't belong, 5.7.

48
00:02:59.501 --> 00:03:04.930
Okay, so
what is the type of first + third?

49
00:03:05.970 --> 00:03:10.359
Well, it's actually a float, and
this is where things get a little iffy.

50
00:03:10.359 --> 00:03:15.237
If I have an integer and a float,
I'm going to get a float through addition,

51
00:03:15.237 --> 00:03:17.170
that's what I'm gonna get.

52
00:03:17.170 --> 00:03:22.427
Integer plus an integer is an integer,
a float plus a float is a float,

53
00:03:22.427 --> 00:03:25.468
float plus an integer is a float as well.

54
00:03:25.468 --> 00:03:30.037
Ultimately, it usually doesn't
matter whatsoever, right?

55
00:03:30.037 --> 00:03:33.740
You're just like, I want a result, I'm
doing some kind of mathematical operation.

56
00:03:33.740 --> 00:03:40.158
Sometimes, though, that last little
decimal place can cause some hiccups.

57
00:03:40.158 --> 00:03:44.135
All right, so you have to remember,
if you have integers and floats and

58
00:03:44.135 --> 00:03:48.808
you're operation with addition, you're
gonna get a floating point as a result.

59
00:03:48.808 --> 00:03:53.508
I'm gonna Ctrl+L and get back up here,
I still have first, second, and third.

60
00:03:53.508 --> 00:03:57.190
Well can I do first- third, yep.

61
00:03:57.190 --> 00:04:00.698
Can I do first- second, I sure can.

62
00:04:00.698 --> 00:04:04.401
Same rules apply as they do in addition.

63
00:04:04.401 --> 00:04:08.250
So what else can I do?

64
00:04:08.250 --> 00:04:13.120
Well, I can do times second,
but what is the type of that?

65
00:04:13.120 --> 00:04:17.099
Because it kinda makes sense
that minus works like addition.

66
00:04:17.099 --> 00:04:21.740
So first * second, well, it's an integer.

67
00:04:21.740 --> 00:04:27.143
What about first * third?

68
00:04:27.143 --> 00:04:30.710
Well, if you add that random
parenthesis there, then it breaks.

69
00:04:30.710 --> 00:04:33.582
But that's first * third,
and what was first?

70
00:04:33.582 --> 00:04:37.390
Well first was 1, so 1 times 4.7 is that.

71
00:04:37.390 --> 00:04:42.420
And well what's the type(first * third),
well, it's a float again.

72
00:04:42.420 --> 00:04:47.644
So if we have a float in there,
somewhere we're gonna get a float result.

73
00:04:47.644 --> 00:04:49.604
What about divide, and

74
00:04:49.604 --> 00:04:55.200
this is where the first whoopsy
daisy kind of starts coming in here.

75
00:04:55.200 --> 00:04:59.038
All right, so let's look at first,
let's look at second.

76
00:04:59.038 --> 00:05:02.939
If we do first / second, hm,

77
00:05:02.939 --> 00:05:07.160
I wonder what we're gonna get.

78
00:05:09.226 --> 00:05:11.446
Well, that actually makes sense.

79
00:05:11.446 --> 00:05:15.334
I'm gonna take a moment and kind of
take a quick detour here, in Python 2,

80
00:05:15.334 --> 00:05:16.960
this is a different behavior.

81
00:05:16.960 --> 00:05:22.875
You will actually get 0 because it will
do what's called integer division.

82
00:05:22.875 --> 00:05:29.200
1 divided by 3, it's gonna say,
does 3 go into 1 a whole number of times?

83
00:05:29.200 --> 00:05:32.910
And it says, no there are 0 3s in 1.

84
00:05:32.910 --> 00:05:35.687
So you'll get a 0 instead of,
well, what was that type?

85
00:05:39.100 --> 00:05:42.524
That's odd because division,
I have an integer and an integer.

86
00:05:42.524 --> 00:05:44.780
But I get a float as a respective result.

87
00:05:44.780 --> 00:05:48.656
>> So in Python 2,
it's like they are holding tried and true,

88
00:05:48.656 --> 00:05:53.530
integers are integers, and we are never
gonna get anything but an integer.

89
00:05:53.530 --> 00:05:58.210
And so help us cod,
[LAUGH] that's what we're going to do.

90
00:05:58.210 --> 00:06:00.031
>> Yep, so it was integer division.

91
00:06:00.031 --> 00:06:02.740
That's actually something they
picked up from previous languages.

92
00:06:02.740 --> 00:06:04.382
This happens in some other
programming languages.

93
00:06:04.382 --> 00:06:09.470
If I have two integers and I operate
with them, then I get an integer back.

94
00:06:09.470 --> 00:06:11.352
>> But that's not right.

95
00:06:11.352 --> 00:06:12.092
>> [LAUGH]
>> I mean,

96
00:06:12.092 --> 00:06:14.190
that kinda breaks the rules of math,
right?

97
00:06:14.190 --> 00:06:17.098
>> Well it breaks the rules of math for
me and you.

98
00:06:17.098 --> 00:06:22.248
But if you say I have integers and
integers, technically,

99
00:06:22.248 --> 00:06:26.820
why would I get a float if I
take these two data types?

100
00:06:26.820 --> 00:06:33.320
I have this implied change of data types
that just kind of appears out of nowhere.

101
00:06:33.320 --> 00:06:35.137
I can kind of understand an integer and
a float.

102
00:06:35.137 --> 00:06:39.070
You're like, I gotta get a float, because
I may have floating point numbers now.

103
00:06:39.070 --> 00:06:42.724
But if I have an integer and an integer
and it goes, well I'm just gonna go over

104
00:06:42.724 --> 00:06:46.200
here and pick a random number to
represent that, then it gets weird.

105
00:06:46.200 --> 00:06:51.165
But by and large, when we learned math
in school, this is how we'd learn it.

106
00:06:51.165 --> 00:06:57.150
Even if we write 1 with no decimal point,
divided by 3, we'll go, that's 0.3333.

107
00:06:57.150 --> 00:07:02.062
In computers, though, those are actually
two different types of numbers.

108
00:07:02.062 --> 00:07:05.650
Typically, some programming languages
kind of muddy that water even more, so

109
00:07:05.650 --> 00:07:07.016
just be careful there.

110
00:07:07.016 --> 00:07:11.608
>> I keep forgetting that computers
don't think like us, and so

111
00:07:11.608 --> 00:07:14.715
we have to conform to
them in how we write.

112
00:07:14.715 --> 00:07:17.847
But you said two to three, so obviously,

113
00:07:17.847 --> 00:07:21.170
this was causing problems
in how it worked.

114
00:07:21.170 --> 00:07:25.613
So Python 3, within its language,
decided to say,

115
00:07:25.613 --> 00:07:30.473
you can go ahead and
change yourself in these situations.

116
00:07:30.473 --> 00:07:36.720
From an integer to a float because
we're going to obey the rules of math.

117
00:07:36.720 --> 00:07:38.980
>> Yeah,
we're gonna obey how people think,

118
00:07:38.980 --> 00:07:41.550
we want this to be easy to reason about.

119
00:07:41.550 --> 00:07:43.980
Two numbers divided,
I could get a floating point number.

120
00:07:43.980 --> 00:07:47.044
Now something that I do wanna show,
though.

121
00:07:47.044 --> 00:07:50.680
Is if I go second / second, so
a number divided by itself,

122
00:07:50.680 --> 00:07:53.140
notice it's still int divided by int.

123
00:07:53.140 --> 00:07:57.414
But I get 1.0,
which is a floating point number,

124
00:07:57.414 --> 00:08:00.436
even though it is an exact division.

125
00:08:00.436 --> 00:08:03.208
That's the tricky part.

126
00:08:03.208 --> 00:08:05.405
However, because this behavior changed and

127
00:08:05.405 --> 00:08:08.354
they needed the ability for
some backwards compatibility,

128
00:08:08.354 --> 00:08:12.249
there's a secondary operator that allows
you to use the old style in Python 3.

129
00:08:12.249 --> 00:08:14.170
All right?

130
00:08:14.170 --> 00:08:20.500
If I want just the whole
number amount of times, right?

131
00:08:20.500 --> 00:08:24.162
That it goes in, so if I say,

132
00:08:24.162 --> 00:08:28.610
first // second, two slashes.

133
00:08:28.610 --> 00:08:30.550
And actually get 0, which is an integer.

134
00:08:30.550 --> 00:08:31.431
I get integer division.

135
00:08:31.431 --> 00:08:38.500
With the now slash, not the old one, is
just more or less floating point division.

136
00:08:38.500 --> 00:08:42.190
I have two different division operators
based on the respective data type.

137
00:08:43.330 --> 00:08:48.460
>> I can see why you might want
this to be like the old way.

138
00:08:48.460 --> 00:08:53.410
And this is obviously a big change in the
syntax from two to three is that you now

139
00:08:53.410 --> 00:08:56.340
have this slash slash vs single slash.

140
00:08:56.340 --> 00:09:02.110
And there are going to be cases where I
don't want you to change to a float or

141
00:09:02.110 --> 00:09:02.700
decimal.

142
00:09:02.700 --> 00:09:06.240
It's almost like round up to the nearest
whole number or something to that effect.

143
00:09:06.240 --> 00:09:08.370
Exactly, give me the whole
number representation.

144
00:09:08.370 --> 00:09:12.420
And this actually causes you to
have to think about this more.

145
00:09:12.420 --> 00:09:15.770
But what it also means is,
you have to think about it more so

146
00:09:15.770 --> 00:09:19.800
you have to reason about it, so you
have to make a decision, don't / or //.

147
00:09:19.800 --> 00:09:21.340
So you just have to be careful there.

148
00:09:21.340 --> 00:09:22.425
>> We have to be humans again.

149
00:09:22.425 --> 00:09:23.290
[LAUGH]
>> We have to be.

150
00:09:23.290 --> 00:09:25.340
I know, it's hard, it's hard.

151
00:09:25.340 --> 00:09:29.880
But that's one of the weird nuances
that kinda break as we first get there.

152
00:09:29.880 --> 00:09:32.300
Now these are not the only things
that we can do with numbers.

153
00:09:32.300 --> 00:09:35.160
There's a few other things
that are gonna crop up.

154
00:09:35.160 --> 00:09:37.170
Because I'm already with division.

155
00:09:37.170 --> 00:09:41.280
I'm actually gonna do something
else called the modulus operator or

156
00:09:41.280 --> 00:09:42.690
the modular operator.

157
00:09:42.690 --> 00:09:49.610
You've heard it both ways, or sometimes
it's called mod, people shorten it.

158
00:09:49.610 --> 00:09:56.928
And what that means is, well let's say
I have, I'm gonna do this, second is 3.

159
00:09:56.928 --> 00:10:00.835
I wanna abandon these variables just for
a moment, just to show some numbers.

160
00:10:00.835 --> 00:10:05.826
So, I'm gonna say 3 % 3.

161
00:10:05.826 --> 00:10:08.850
This percent sign is the modulo operator.

162
00:10:09.890 --> 00:10:12.150
If I hit Enter, I get Zebra.

163
00:10:12.150 --> 00:10:15.285
What is the type?

164
00:10:15.285 --> 00:10:17.660
3 mod 3.
What's an integer?

165
00:10:17.660 --> 00:10:18.364
Okay, keep that in mind.

166
00:10:18.364 --> 00:10:22.630
I'm gonna show you a few examples before
we talk about what it actually does.

167
00:10:22.630 --> 00:10:25.170
All right, so 3 or excuse me.

168
00:10:25.170 --> 00:10:29.740
4 mod 3 is 1.

169
00:10:29.740 --> 00:10:30.850
What is the type?

170
00:10:30.850 --> 00:10:31.720
4 mod 3.

171
00:10:32.930 --> 00:10:33.520
Still an integer.

172
00:10:34.750 --> 00:10:37.960
5 mod 3 is 2.

173
00:10:37.960 --> 00:10:41.700
Notice there's no .0, so I'm pretty
certain that's an integer as well.

174
00:10:41.700 --> 00:10:43.989
What about 6 mod 3?

175
00:10:43.989 --> 00:10:46.000
We're back to 0.

176
00:10:47.650 --> 00:10:49.150
It's kinda odd, right?

177
00:10:49.150 --> 00:10:52.477
However, whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa, Justin.

178
00:10:52.477 --> 00:10:55.900
3 divided by 3 divides evenly.

179
00:10:55.900 --> 00:10:58.296
There is 0 remainder.

180
00:10:58.296 --> 00:11:02.261
4 divided by 3, 3 goes into 4 one time but
there's one left over.

181
00:11:02.261 --> 00:11:04.280
We have 1 remainder.

182
00:11:04.280 --> 00:11:07.660
5 divided by 3, goes in one time.

183
00:11:07.660 --> 00:11:09.400
But there's actually two things left over.

184
00:11:09.400 --> 00:11:14.590
But 3 goes into 6,
two times evenly with zero remainder.

185
00:11:14.590 --> 00:11:19.060
So, division will give you how
many times you can divide.

186
00:11:19.060 --> 00:11:23.960
Modulus gives you what is the amount
of things left over that did not divide

187
00:11:23.960 --> 00:11:25.090
evenly.

188
00:11:25.090 --> 00:11:26.090
And if you're like wait a minute,

189
00:11:26.090 --> 00:11:29.280
this sounds familiar, you probably
learned this in elementary school.

190
00:11:29.280 --> 00:11:32.060
And then we said forget about it,
it's not useful.

191
00:11:32.060 --> 00:11:32.890
I'm telling you here,

192
00:11:32.890 --> 00:11:37.990
this ends up being very useful in
programming a variety of things.

193
00:11:37.990 --> 00:11:41.663
>> I was waiting because I know we
talked about this in another episode and

194
00:11:41.663 --> 00:11:43.666
I was like, I forgot what this means.

195
00:11:43.666 --> 00:11:44.812
>> [LAUGH]
>> What, and

196
00:11:44.812 --> 00:11:47.900
then as soon as you started going
through it, it's the remainder.

197
00:11:47.900 --> 00:11:53.680
It was that whole, you do your division
and you do R 2, and that's the leftovers.

198
00:11:54.750 --> 00:11:56.450
I got it back.

199
00:11:56.450 --> 00:11:59.252
I've come back around full circle and
I'm back at 0.

200
00:11:59.252 --> 00:12:00.050
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

201
00:12:00.050 --> 00:12:01.249
>> So Modulo and

202
00:12:01.249 --> 00:12:04.195
division kinda go hand in hand.

203
00:12:04.195 --> 00:12:08.060
Right, they give you the two
sides of the respective coin.

204
00:12:08.060 --> 00:12:12.600
Now, okay, we can do division,
add, subtract, multiply, divide.

205
00:12:12.600 --> 00:12:13.940
And Modulus.

206
00:12:13.940 --> 00:12:18.620
But we have a few other numeric
operations that we can have.

207
00:12:20.180 --> 00:12:22.890
Number one, exponents, right?

208
00:12:22.890 --> 00:12:27.588
So let's clear this out,
and I can say, well, first,

209
00:12:27.588 --> 00:12:30.940
second and okay.

210
00:12:30.940 --> 00:12:36.730
So if I say second * second,
that's 3 times 3, which is 9.

211
00:12:36.730 --> 00:12:41.169
That's really just 3 to the second power,
all right?

212
00:12:41.169 --> 00:12:47.430
So second ** 2.

213
00:12:47.430 --> 00:12:50.640
It's actually 9.

214
00:12:50.640 --> 00:12:52.629
If I do 3, that's 27.

215
00:12:52.629 --> 00:12:55.000
So that's raising it to a power.

216
00:12:55.000 --> 00:12:58.472
Python actually provides you an operator
that does that already for you, so

217
00:12:58.472 --> 00:13:01.020
you don't have to go multiply,
multiply, multiply or

218
00:13:01.020 --> 00:13:02.933
figure out how to do all this other stuff.

219
00:13:02.933 --> 00:13:05.793
If I wanted 5 squared,

220
00:13:05.793 --> 00:13:10.660
I would say 5 ** 2, then we get 25.

221
00:13:10.660 --> 00:13:13.560
That's handy, all right?

222
00:13:13.560 --> 00:13:17.933
And then, well, there's a few other
things that we can do with numbers, and

223
00:13:17.933 --> 00:13:19.161
before we do though.

224
00:13:19.161 --> 00:13:23.739
All right, I almost got ahead of myself,
I'm showing you integers.

225
00:13:23.739 --> 00:13:25.961
What's the type of 5 ** 2?

226
00:13:25.961 --> 00:13:27.418
It's an integer.

227
00:13:27.418 --> 00:13:33.395
What is the type of
third which is 4.7 ** 2?

228
00:13:33.395 --> 00:13:34.776
It's a float.

229
00:13:34.776 --> 00:13:41.242
So third ** 2, is 22,09 but
a lot lot of decimal places there.

230
00:13:41.242 --> 00:13:43.679
And that makes sense, right,

231
00:13:43.679 --> 00:13:49.040
the type is kind of determined by
the base right, what's in front.

232
00:13:50.140 --> 00:13:55.273
But along with that you can
even do crazy things like,

233
00:13:55.273 --> 00:13:58.021
what is second ** 1.2.

234
00:13:58.021 --> 00:14:01.270
Ooh, this is probably something
you don't do a whole lot of.

235
00:14:02.440 --> 00:14:05.350
But, you can do fractional powers.

236
00:14:06.450 --> 00:14:08.710
And as you can see this is a float.

237
00:14:08.710 --> 00:14:12.120
So if I have a float in
either one of those operands,

238
00:14:12.120 --> 00:14:16.650
it's still, still good to go, okay?

239
00:14:16.650 --> 00:14:18.520
So it's still a float.

240
00:14:18.520 --> 00:14:22.717
If we have third ** 1.2.

241
00:14:22.717 --> 00:14:25.314
It's still a float, okay?

242
00:14:25.314 --> 00:14:27.995
So those are very particular use cases but

243
00:14:27.995 --> 00:14:32.430
I just wanna get you to thinking
about the respective times.

244
00:14:32.430 --> 00:14:37.463
>> Was that the same in Python 2,
or is this a Python 3 upgrade?

245
00:14:37.463 --> 00:14:39.593
>> This is still the same in Python 2.

246
00:14:39.593 --> 00:14:42.097
I strongly recommend everybody
staying in Python 3, but

247
00:14:42.097 --> 00:14:45.364
there may be some times where you're
gonna encounter some Python 2 code and

248
00:14:45.364 --> 00:14:47.660
it's good to know about
these nuance differences.

249
00:14:47.660 --> 00:14:50.950
Powers, so this is the power operator.

250
00:14:50.950 --> 00:14:54.540
Exactly the same thing, so all good to go.

251
00:14:54.540 --> 00:14:58.500
So remember, numbers have an int and
a float, int and a float.

252
00:14:58.500 --> 00:15:01.920
Division is the one where it
gets a little iffy, right?

253
00:15:01.920 --> 00:15:06.090
We can do powers and
there's a few other things.

254
00:15:06.090 --> 00:15:09.680
If I'm not mistaken,
this should be available in your ABS.

255
00:15:09.680 --> 00:15:11.450
Not anti lock brake systems.

256
00:15:11.450 --> 00:15:13.560
Totally a different thing.

257
00:15:13.560 --> 00:15:17.406
I can say ABS, the absolute value.

258
00:15:17.406 --> 00:15:22.634
So if I say abs(-3), it's 3.

259
00:15:22.634 --> 00:15:27.921
abs(3), essentially just give
me how far away from 0 it is.

260
00:15:27.921 --> 00:15:35.048
And you'll notice that if I say abs(3) and
finish that, it's an int.

261
00:15:35.048 --> 00:15:39.750
Let say abs(3.2), it's a float.

262
00:15:39.750 --> 00:15:45.480
So it's kinda dependent on
the respective input operator.

263
00:15:45.480 --> 00:15:52.090
So I have absolute value, power, division,
multiplication, modulus, add subtract.

264
00:15:52.090 --> 00:15:54.746
And I do wanna show you this.

265
00:15:54.746 --> 00:15:55.998
We're kinda jumping ahead a little bit.

266
00:15:55.998 --> 00:16:01.073
There are some other things that you can
do in Python, but they're not available.

267
00:16:01.073 --> 00:16:07.135
Right out of the box,
like square root, or sqrt.

268
00:16:07.135 --> 00:16:10.070
However, we'll eventually get to these.

269
00:16:11.370 --> 00:16:14.540
Python comes built in with other things
that you can say hey, you know what?

00:16:14.540 --> 00:16:17.550
I need this toolbox just for

271

So import math, and you're like,

272
00:16:23.610 --> 00:16:28.890
But what math provides us is another

273
00:16:28.890 --> 00:16:33.250
Notice all of the other ones have just
been these kind of operators, except for

274
00:16:33.250 --> 00:16:37.860
abs and sqrt.

275
00:16:37.860 --> 00:16:41.040
I'm only showing you this,
math has a whole bunch of these.

276
00:16:41.040 --> 00:16:45.354
Those are functions, it'll be a little bit
before we write out own functions, but

277
00:16:45.354 --> 00:16:46.781
you need to know function.

278
00:16:46.781 --> 00:16:50.130
You give it some information and
it spits out some information.

279
00:16:50.130 --> 00:16:54.098
So if I say, what is the square
root of second or three?

280
00:16:54.098 --> 00:16:57.792
Well, math.sqrt(second),

281
00:16:57.792 --> 00:17:02.140
square root of second or three is 1.73.

282
00:17:02.140 --> 00:17:03.620
It's a float.

283
00:17:03.620 --> 00:17:07.636
Well, what about math.sqrt(4)?

284
00:17:07.636 --> 00:17:11.740
Square root of 4 is 2, except it's float.

285
00:17:11.740 --> 00:17:15.030
Square root always returns
float regardless of the input.

286
00:17:15.030 --> 00:17:17.040
So I intentionally did that to show you,

287
00:17:17.040 --> 00:17:20.010
you gotta be careful
about what's returned.

288
00:17:20.010 --> 00:17:22.750
Square root's always gonna give
you a float, absolute value or

289
00:17:22.750 --> 00:17:27.950
abs is gonna be dependent
on what is passed in, okay?

290
00:17:29.260 --> 00:17:31.480
So those are a lot of
the operations that you can do.

291
00:17:31.480 --> 00:17:34.020
But you're like,
well wait a minute, Justin.

292
00:17:34.020 --> 00:17:35.940
You say these are number,
they all have the same behavior,

293
00:17:35.940 --> 00:17:39.790
but what if I want, I get a float back,
but I want it to be an integer?

294
00:17:41.420 --> 00:17:44.830
What if I'm an integer, but
I wanted to be a float, all right?

295
00:17:45.960 --> 00:17:49.130
Well, let's say this, let's say first.

296
00:17:49.130 --> 00:17:51.110
This is some result, right?

297
00:17:51.110 --> 00:17:53.460
You did 3 divided by 3.

298
00:17:53.460 --> 00:17:55.690
Yeah, but I really want the float version.

299
00:17:57.500 --> 00:18:00.450
Well, if you did the regular slash,
you would get the float version.

300
00:18:00.450 --> 00:18:07.060
But if I wanted this to be a float,
I could say float(first),

301
00:18:07.060 --> 00:18:11.330
and then I will get the floating
point representation of that integer.

302
00:18:11.330 --> 00:18:13.900
It actually changes it and hands back.

303
00:18:13.900 --> 00:18:17.250
But it doesn't change the variable,
so be careful there.

304
00:18:17.250 --> 00:18:22.040
>> So that's a function, you're telling
it to do something to this variable.

305
00:18:22.040 --> 00:18:24.820
>> Yeah, and do something to
the value contained in the variable.

306
00:18:24.820 --> 00:18:27.320
You have to be careful,
we're not reassigning the variable.

307
00:18:27.320 --> 00:18:32.850
If we wanted to,
then we would say like that,

308
00:18:32.850 --> 00:18:38.080
and now first is the floating point,
version of the original value.

309
00:18:38.080 --> 00:18:43.380
>> Good clarification on the words
that I'm using to describe this.

310
00:18:43.380 --> 00:18:46.900
Because that's the, no, that actually
means a little bit different if you took

311
00:18:46.900 --> 00:18:48.820
it at face value of exactly what I said.

312
00:18:48.820 --> 00:18:51.400
So what you said was
what I was trying to say.

313
00:18:51.400 --> 00:18:54.360
And then, of course, the float.

314
00:18:54.360 --> 00:18:57.660
Is int the other function?

315
00:18:57.660 --> 00:19:01.170
>> See, this is what I love about
Python is I was like, here's float, and

00:19:01.170 --> 00:19:03.790
Vonne's like, well there must be an int.

317
00:19:03.790 --> 00:19:04.670
Let's find out.

318
00:19:04.670 --> 00:19:09.560
We know that third is a float, like that?

319
00:19:09.560 --> 00:19:10.060
>> Yeah.

320
00:19:10.060 --> 00:19:12.360
>> Boom, it is, it works.

321
00:19:12.360 --> 00:19:17.010
Notice though,
I don't necessarily lose information,

322
00:19:17.010 --> 00:19:20.300
I may lose some precision,
right, how close to the number.

323
00:19:20.300 --> 00:19:24.070
Notice 1 and 1.0, you're like,
those are the same.

324
00:19:24.070 --> 00:19:26.840
If I take a floating point number and
make it an integer, though,

325
00:19:26.840 --> 00:19:28.805
I actually lose all
the decimal information.

326
00:19:28.805 --> 00:19:32.780
4.7 and 4, I would argue,
are drastically different things.

327
00:19:32.780 --> 00:19:37.071
And if you don't believe me Which one
would you rather get paid per hour, 4 or

328
00:19:37.071 --> 00:19:37.610
4,7?

329
00:19:37.610 --> 00:19:40.334
Well neither one because they're
both below minimum wage, but

330
00:19:40.334 --> 00:19:41.620
besides that, right?

331
00:19:41.620 --> 00:19:43.390
So you have to be careful there.

332
00:19:43.390 --> 00:19:47.710
>> I was doing the human thing again of,
that's five, because we're doing our rules

333
00:19:47.710 --> 00:19:52.810
of rounding, and
it does not round, it drops.

334
00:19:52.810 --> 00:19:53.880
>> Yep, it truncates.

335
00:19:53.880 --> 00:19:57.290
So it says, cool give me all the things
to the left of the decimal place,

336
00:19:57.290 --> 00:19:58.940
who cares about to the right.

337
00:19:58.940 --> 00:20:02.400
And it slices it off and hands you
back the whole number, and more or

338
00:20:02.400 --> 00:20:04.410
less does what's called a floor.

339
00:20:06.170 --> 00:20:08.800
Integer, more or less,
does that to floats.

340
00:20:08.800 --> 00:20:11.970
If I type int(1), I just, more or

341
00:20:11.970 --> 00:20:14.990
less, get 1 back, so
there's nothing changing there.

342
00:20:14.990 --> 00:20:18.670
But if it is a floating point number,
you will lose information, so to speak.

343
00:20:18.670 --> 00:20:21.800
>> And we're just talking about data types
right now, so we're going to stop there.

344
00:20:21.800 --> 00:20:24.310
But you can round up.

345
00:20:24.310 --> 00:20:27.020
There's something in
the language that says,

346
00:20:27.020 --> 00:20:31.960
I want you to take this value, and
round up to the nearest whole number.

347
00:20:31.960 --> 00:20:32.700
>> And it's funny, Vonne,

348
00:20:32.700 --> 00:20:34.780
cuz you're talking about a lot
of math functions there.

349
00:20:34.780 --> 00:20:38.410
It might even be in that
import math thing that we did.

350
00:20:38.410 --> 00:20:42.810
But now I'm thinking, since we're really
worried about the delineation between

351
00:20:42.810 --> 00:20:46.560
floats and integers,
we may have to save that to a later time.

352
00:20:46.560 --> 00:20:49.910
>> I want to do it, but I had to get it
out cuz it's just in my thought process.

353
00:20:49.910 --> 00:20:51.290
I'm like, I know you can.

354
00:20:51.290 --> 00:20:55.550
You don't have to show me, but
just let me know that it's available and

355
00:20:55.550 --> 00:20:59.540
I'll say, all right, I'll patiently wait
for you to tell me about how to do that.

356
00:20:59.540 --> 00:21:02.240
Well, thank you so much for
clarifying those data types.

357
00:21:02.240 --> 00:21:04.820
Nice little stroll down math memory lane.

358
00:21:04.820 --> 00:21:07.870
I was a little scared there for
awhile, being a humanities major.

359
00:21:07.870 --> 00:21:11.730
But thank you for that, and thank you for
joining us, but we're gonna go ahead and

360
00:21:11.730 --> 00:21:13.130
wrap up this one.

361
00:21:13.130 --> 00:21:15.880
For DevProTV,
I've been your host, Vonne Smith.

362
00:21:15.880 --> 00:21:16.620
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

363
00:21:16.620 --> 00:21:17.681
>> And we'll see you soon.
