I don't have to figure things out.

464
00:27:46.237 --> 00:27:48.730
I'm like, well I was trying to play
around on the repo a little bit.

465
00:27:48.730 --> 00:27:52.950
If you type help and then the thing,

466
00:27:52.950 --> 00:27:56.170
it will give you kind of
the documentation right up front.

467
00:27:56.170 --> 00:27:59.610
And then when you're done, you just hit q,
and then you're back out of it.

468
00:27:59.610 --> 00:28:02.920
So all of these things a string can do,
and you'll probably use these at some

469
00:28:02.920 --> 00:28:07.880
point, capitalize,
sometimes it's fun to build your own.

470
00:28:07.880 --> 00:28:11.180
But you can capitalize,
you can title case, you can translate,

471
00:28:11.180 --> 00:28:15.260
you can partition, you can see if it's
printable, is it lower, is it numeric.

472
00:28:15.260 --> 00:28:21.072
Very useful, but if you ever wonder,
how do I do, what is zfill,

473
00:28:21.072 --> 00:28:27.140
well, check out with help parentheses and
then a string dot zfill.

474
00:28:27.140 --> 00:28:30.215
Read the docs, figure it out,
and poke at it a little bit.

475
00:28:30.215 --> 00:28:33.670
And to some extent, you have to get used
to doing that in programming anyway.

476
00:28:33.670 --> 00:28:36.010
But we've seen a few
new things in the repo,

477
00:28:36.010 --> 00:28:39.880
we've seen some of the non-obvious
things with strings.

478
00:28:39.880 --> 00:28:43.650
But we also learned that strings
have a lot more capabilities than we

479
00:28:43.650 --> 00:28:44.340
originally thought.

480
00:28:44.340 --> 00:28:46.440
They're zero indexed, we can slice and

481
00:28:46.440 --> 00:28:48.750
dice them,
we can get individual characters.

482
00:28:48.750 --> 00:28:51.380
We can add them together,
which is concatenation.

483
00:28:51.380 --> 00:28:55.302
But we can also multiply them
with numbers and get repeats,

484
00:28:55.302 --> 00:29:00.097
as well as all of those other methods
that we've seen kind of listed out.

485
00:29:00.097 --> 00:29:03.387
A lot going on with strings, and they just
keep on coming back, but for I think now,

486
00:29:03.387 --> 00:29:05.290
that's a pretty good stopping point.

487
00:29:05.290 --> 00:29:07.846
>> Yeah, I like that help at the end,
it's kinda like in Excel,

488
00:29:07.846 --> 00:29:09.235
the insert function dialog box.

489
00:29:09.235 --> 00:29:12.418
Where it actually tells you
each part of the function and

490
00:29:12.418 --> 00:29:16.426
things that you don't really need
to know about if you don't need it.

491
00:29:16.426 --> 00:29:20.570
But at least it tells you what's going on,
so thank you for that.

492
00:29:20.570 --> 00:29:24.090
Lot of things that I was not expecting,
but pleasantly surprised

493
00:29:24.090 --> 00:29:27.290
at what we could do with strings,
so thank you so much for that.

494
00:29:27.290 --> 00:29:30.835
I really enjoyed this episode, good one,
so I hope you liked it as well.

495
00:29:30.835 --> 00:29:32.610
But we're gonna go ahead and
wrap this one up.

496
00:29:32.610 --> 00:29:35.316
Signing off for DevProTV,
I've been your host, Vonne Smith.

497
00:29:35.316 --> 00:29:36.053
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

498
00:29:36.053 --> 00:29:38.405
>> And we'll see you soon.

499
00:29:38.405 --> 00:29:43.452
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore the boolean data type. Justin further explores the use of booleans and operations involving booleans as well as highlights the common uses of booleans.
episodes.title: Basic Data Types: Booleans
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:13.096 --> 00:00:17.120
Hello everyone and welcome back to
another exciting edition of DevProTV.

3
00:00:17.120 --> 00:00:18.450
I'm your host, Vonne Smith, and

4
00:00:18.450 --> 00:00:21.085
we are moving through our
Programming Fundamentals series.

5
00:00:21.085 --> 00:00:25.361
In this episode, we're gonna be taking
a closer look at the Boolean data type.

6
00:00:25.361 --> 00:00:27.390
And here to help us is Mr.
Justin Dennison.

7
00:00:27.390 --> 00:00:29.122
How are you?
>> I'm doing fantastic, Vonne.

8
00:00:29.122 --> 00:00:31.080
How are you?
>> I'm doing pretty good.

9
00:00:31.080 --> 00:00:33.950
Now I know with some of our other
episodes with the numbers and

10
00:00:33.950 --> 00:00:38.340
the strings, lots of cool information
that I was pretty excited about.

11
00:00:39.520 --> 00:00:42.056
I'm not sure how excited I'm
gonna get about Booleans.

12
00:00:42.056 --> 00:00:44.090
I thought Booleans are just on and off.

13
00:00:44.090 --> 00:00:46.230
How much more do we have with on and off?

14
00:00:46.230 --> 00:00:49.850
[LAUGH]
>> That can be tricky.

15
00:00:49.850 --> 00:00:53.510
There's not as much involved as those
two respective previous episodes with

16
00:00:53.510 --> 00:00:54.570
numbers and strings.

17
00:00:54.570 --> 00:00:56.650
But Booleans can, well,

18
00:00:56.650 --> 00:01:01.380
not can, they are very important to
developing a larger scale program.

19
00:01:01.380 --> 00:01:04.840
They are the cornerstone of logic, right?

20
00:01:04.840 --> 00:01:07.750
So you can think of, do I like cheese?

21
00:01:07.750 --> 00:01:12.460
Yes, right, that is true,
Justin likes cheese, true.

22
00:01:12.460 --> 00:01:16.720
By combining these,
you can branch things off and

23
00:01:16.720 --> 00:01:21.521
have your program be more reactive,
more flowcharty,

24
00:01:21.521 --> 00:01:26.050
or you come to a path in the woods and
you gotta take the left or the right.

25
00:01:26.050 --> 00:01:28.930
That's essentially what
Booleans provide to you.

26
00:01:28.930 --> 00:01:31.044
>> Yeah, I just realized, I'm like, wow.

27
00:01:31.044 --> 00:01:34.251
I was just,
this is just some fleeting thing.

28
00:01:34.251 --> 00:01:36.776
And I'm like, this is everything.

29
00:01:36.776 --> 00:01:41.193
If you do this, then you do that.

30
00:01:41.193 --> 00:01:43.465
As soon as you went with the flowchart,
I was like, yeah,

31
00:01:43.465 --> 00:01:44.590
these are really important.

32
00:01:44.590 --> 00:01:45.140
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

33
00:01:45.140 --> 00:01:48.110
and it's weird because they seem so
simple.

34
00:01:48.110 --> 00:01:50.460
You're like, there's two values,
true and false.

35
00:01:50.460 --> 00:01:53.160
Those are the only two
values that you have.

36
00:01:53.160 --> 00:01:54.200
That's correct, right?

37
00:01:54.200 --> 00:01:56.170
That's actually a true statement.

38
00:01:56.170 --> 00:02:01.680
However, Booleans can be combined with so
many complex operators and

39
00:02:01.680 --> 00:02:06.100
can actually have a conversion
between some of the other types,

40
00:02:06.100 --> 00:02:09.830
because Python gets a little
shaky on some of the other types.

41
00:02:09.830 --> 00:02:14.520
Then it doesn't end up being as simple
as one would initially think, all right?

42
00:02:14.520 --> 00:02:16.620
But we've talked about it.

43
00:02:16.620 --> 00:02:20.780
Let's go ahead and poke around in
the REPL with Boolean data types.

44
00:02:20.780 --> 00:02:25.381
So let's go and take a look at the screen
here, and I'm gonna hop inside of REPL.

45
00:02:25.381 --> 00:02:30.224
I know some of you are like, you know,
we installed that text editor way back.

46
00:02:30.224 --> 00:02:31.530
When are we gonna use that?

47
00:02:31.530 --> 00:02:35.730
We're gonna get there, but these initial
ones, there's not a lot of impetus for

48
00:02:35.730 --> 00:02:38.430
switching between screens and
things like that.

49
00:02:38.430 --> 00:02:42.100
So I'm trying to keep it simple so we can
focus on their respective concepts, right?

50
00:02:42.100 --> 00:02:47.640
The goal with a REPL is to poke around,
to see things, to reason about them,

51
00:02:47.640 --> 00:02:51.809
but try to build deeper understanding,
not just [NOISE].

52
00:02:51.809 --> 00:02:55.196
Once we get to more complicated things,
then we'll use our text editor and

53
00:02:55.196 --> 00:02:57.286
it'll make a little more sense, all right?

54
00:02:57.286 --> 00:03:00.038
So that's all right.

55
00:03:00.038 --> 00:03:01.270
Let's go ahead and clear this out.

56
00:03:01.270 --> 00:03:04.865
And let's say, I don't know, likes_cheese.

57
00:03:04.865 --> 00:03:09.753
And if you're just now joining us,
likes_cheese and cheese,

58
00:03:09.753 --> 00:03:12.970
they're pretty common theme with me.

59
00:03:12.970 --> 00:03:16.466
So it's all right, likes_cheese and
then, I don't know,

60
00:03:16.466 --> 00:03:21.440
likes_heights, = False, all right?

61
00:03:21.440 --> 00:03:22.213
These are the two.

62
00:03:22.213 --> 00:03:25.844
We've seen these in previous episodes,
capital T, True, capital F, False.

63
00:03:25.844 --> 00:03:26.987
These are special values.

64
00:03:26.987 --> 00:03:27.920
These are reserved words.

65
00:03:27.920 --> 00:03:30.715
You don't see them on the REPL,
but you will see them later on.

66
00:03:30.715 --> 00:03:33.350
They'll get color-coded
because they're special.

67
00:03:33.350 --> 00:03:38.339
And then if I look at the types of these,
So

68
00:03:38.339 --> 00:03:43.850
True, not types, type, the type of that.

69
00:03:43.850 --> 00:03:47.829
And then I just type type(True), type.

70
00:03:47.829 --> 00:03:50.582
[LAUGH] There you go, Vonne.

71
00:03:50.582 --> 00:03:53.311
Sometimes things get a little,
I got excited about cheese and

72
00:03:53.311 --> 00:03:54.685
then it got all twisted there.

73
00:03:54.685 --> 00:03:56.394
[LAUGH]
>> I was curious, I'm like,

74
00:03:56.394 --> 00:03:58.188
is this a new way of testing something?

75
00:03:58.188 --> 00:03:59.743
Is this specific to Booleans?

76
00:03:59.743 --> 00:04:01.516
I'm like, I don't think that's right.

77
00:04:01.516 --> 00:04:04.320
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, it wasn't, but we fixed it,

78
00:04:04.320 --> 00:04:05.730
it's all right now.

79
00:04:05.730 --> 00:04:10.860
And then,
what is the type of likes_heights?

80
00:04:10.860 --> 00:04:12.640
Like so, bool.

81
00:04:12.640 --> 00:04:17.515
Now, in the previous episode with strings,
right at the end, I showed you a couple of

82
00:04:17.515 --> 00:04:22.055
things that can be incredibly helpful
when exploring these data types, like,

83
00:04:22.055 --> 00:04:23.092
what can happen?

84
00:04:23.092 --> 00:04:26.751
So we're gonna start there because
any time look at new things,

85
00:04:26.751 --> 00:04:28.460
I recommend starting there.

86
00:04:29.480 --> 00:04:36.943
These two functions, dir,
right, the dir of likes_cheese.

87
00:04:36.943 --> 00:04:40.483
And because this is a Boolean data type,
that's what I'm gonna get,

88
00:04:40.483 --> 00:04:42.770
all the thing that this can do.

89
00:04:42.770 --> 00:04:47.495
And, well, I also told you everything that

90
00:04:47.495 --> 00:04:52.103
has an underscore around it, disregard.

91
00:04:52.103 --> 00:04:56.359
But, okay, bit_length, conjugate,

92
00:04:56.359 --> 00:05:00.859
denominator, from_bytes, imaginary or

93
00:05:00.859 --> 00:05:05.030
imag, numerator, real, to_bytes.

94
00:05:05.030 --> 00:05:06.680
It's very interesting.

95
00:05:06.680 --> 00:05:08.730
Those do not sound like Boolean things.

96
00:05:10.180 --> 00:05:15.763
They sound like number things.
>> I'm over here going, I have what?

97
00:05:15.763 --> 00:05:18.800
[LAUGH]
>> And it's funny because

98
00:05:20.460 --> 00:05:23.300
the reason I showed you this is this
is one of the times where you go,

99
00:05:23.300 --> 00:05:28.480
I don't know if this actually,
is this gonna be too helpful for me?

100
00:05:28.480 --> 00:05:30.190
Let's actually take a look here.

101
00:05:30.190 --> 00:05:31.590
Let's just pick one of these.

102
00:05:32.600 --> 00:05:36.610
Let's go to, I don't know,
conjugate, all right?

103
00:05:36.610 --> 00:05:46.320
So I'm gonna say,
help(likes_cheese.conjugate).

104
00:05:46.320 --> 00:05:51.940
And it says, method of builtins.bool
instance returns self,

105
00:05:51.940 --> 00:05:55.030
the complex conjugate of any integer.

106
00:05:55.030 --> 00:05:56.690
It's talking about numbers again.

107
00:05:56.690 --> 00:05:59.478
This is not really helpful, all right?

108
00:05:59.478 --> 00:06:05.469
Now I showed you that to tell you it's not
really helpful, but also to tell you those

109
00:06:05.469 --> 00:06:10.777
reserved words, True and False,
in all actuality, behind the scenes,

110
00:06:10.777 --> 00:06:16.274
they're probably being used as numbers,
like False is zero, True is one.

111
00:06:18.100 --> 00:06:22.843
So kind of behaves like a number, but
they do have reserved words because

112
00:06:22.843 --> 00:06:26.595
it's easier to read,
True versus likes_cheese = 1.

113
00:06:26.595 --> 00:06:29.923
That's ambiguous, but
if I say likes_cheese = True,

114
00:06:29.923 --> 00:06:33.165
then you go, okay.
>> This is where we're trying

115
00:06:33.165 --> 00:06:37.866
to use our human words and then translate
again to the computer words, which really

116
00:06:37.866 --> 00:06:43.110
computers are all about numbers, and
that's what they're computing in the back.

117
00:06:43.110 --> 00:06:44.220
So you gotta do that.

118
00:06:44.220 --> 00:06:48.860
But we don't wanna use ones and zeros as
a yes or no because then it doesn't really

119
00:06:48.860 --> 00:06:51.583
make any sense to us.
>> Exactly, and

120
00:06:51.583 --> 00:06:55.645
it's one of those things where
that's probably the case.

121
00:06:55.645 --> 00:06:58.080
I'm not making a strong assertion.

122
00:06:58.080 --> 00:07:01.080
It doesn't really matter
other than the fact

123
00:07:01.080 --> 00:07:04.140
that when you try to use some
of the things you just learned,

124
00:07:04.140 --> 00:07:08.680
it's not quite as helpful as it should
have been or as you anticipate it to be.

125
00:07:08.680 --> 00:07:11.772
You're like, conjugate, numerator,
denominator, wait a minute,

126
00:07:11.772 --> 00:07:12.897
these are number things.

127
00:07:12.897 --> 00:07:19.780
They are, but it's more than likely that
bool is like a number behind the scenes.

128
00:07:19.780 --> 00:07:23.050
But for us,
we're just worried about true and false.

129
00:07:24.270 --> 00:07:29.255
But before we move on to all
the things that bools can do,

130
00:07:29.255 --> 00:07:34.150
right, or can derive from is,
well, let's do this.

131
00:07:35.290 --> 00:07:37.271
Let's clear this out.

132
00:07:37.271 --> 00:07:44.775
And let's say Vonne's
favorite number is 7, right?

133
00:07:44.775 --> 00:07:50.251
And well, okay,
what can I do if I say bool,

134
00:07:50.251 --> 00:07:56.467
or what does it mean,
rather, favorite number.

135
00:07:56.467 --> 00:07:57.985
What's the bool of favorite number?

136
00:07:57.985 --> 00:08:00.603
This is a new function.

137
00:08:00.603 --> 00:08:06.046
And this is saying give me the boolean
representation of the favorite number.

138
00:08:06.046 --> 00:08:11.418
This is where Python gets a little [SOUND]
cuz if I hit Enter it actually says true.

139
00:08:11.418 --> 00:08:17.790
And the reason being if I
say bool(0) I get false but

140
00:08:17.790 --> 00:08:22.038
the bool (-1) I get 0 is false,

141
00:08:22.038 --> 00:08:26.299
anything else is true, all right?

142
00:08:26.299 --> 00:08:30.338
That actually plays in because as
we start learning more about logic,

143
00:08:30.338 --> 00:08:34.865
this fact can actually cause things to
go a little awry if you're not careful.

144
00:08:34.865 --> 00:08:39.774
Because behind the scenes, even if you
don't call this bool, Python will go,

145
00:08:39.774 --> 00:08:42.797
I'm gonna make that make
sense in this context.

146
00:08:42.797 --> 00:08:47.606
It will force your hand, and do some
weird things if you're not aware of this.

147
00:08:47.606 --> 00:08:49.633
>> And this is not just a Python thing,

148
00:08:49.633 --> 00:08:50.855
this is everything.

149
00:08:50.855 --> 00:08:56.640
Because I do this in Excel and
have to talk about what true and

150
00:08:56.640 --> 00:08:59.664
false or words, or anything.

151
00:08:59.664 --> 00:09:04.805
If you put any word in this particular
function, it's gonna count it as 1.

152
00:09:04.805 --> 00:09:09.061
Only if you type false, it's 0.

153
00:09:09.061 --> 00:09:11.535
So this is ubiquitous, right?

154
00:09:11.535 --> 00:09:12.495
Am I using that correctly?

155
00:09:12.495 --> 00:09:14.479
Across the board.
>> It's fairly ubiquitous.

156
00:09:14.479 --> 00:09:18.911
There are a few languages that have
a little bit different edge case rules.

157
00:09:18.911 --> 00:09:23.789
Like well unless it's this particular
thing and then it'll coerce to false, or

158
00:09:23.789 --> 00:09:25.370
it'll change it to false.

159
00:09:25.370 --> 00:09:29.987
But for the most part 0 is false,
everything else is true.

160
00:09:29.987 --> 00:09:34.920
And I say that, to show you a couple
of these edge cases, all right.

161
00:09:34.920 --> 00:09:39.220
So if I say bool of,
there's two quotes no spaces nothing,

162
00:09:39.220 --> 00:09:45.154
this is what's called an empty string,
is false, that means there's nothing,

163
00:09:45.154 --> 00:09:49.639
and the reason being is what's
the length of an empty string?

164
00:09:49.639 --> 00:09:52.231
It's 0 so it makes it false.

165
00:09:52.231 --> 00:09:56.243
Likewise, if I say the bool(1,2,3).

166
00:09:56.243 --> 00:09:57.863
That's a list, we've seen that,

167
00:09:57.863 --> 00:10:00.520
we haven't quite covered what
all of those things can do.

168
00:10:00.520 --> 00:10:01.632
Well that's true.

169
00:10:01.632 --> 00:10:07.409
But what if I say the bool
of an empty list?

170
00:10:07.409 --> 00:10:08.417
Well that's false.

171
00:10:08.417 --> 00:10:09.392
And why is that?

172
00:10:09.392 --> 00:10:14.397
Well that's because the length, and I'm
intentionally jumping ahead just a little

173
00:10:14.397 --> 00:10:18.984
bit here to show you if you think about
these in terms of patterns, then you go

174
00:10:18.984 --> 00:10:23.595
that makes sense if the empty string
has a length, okay, collection type.

175
00:10:23.595 --> 00:10:27.164
If it's an empty collection
it's probably gonna be false.

176
00:10:27.164 --> 00:10:29.940
If it's a full collection,
it's gonna be true.

177
00:10:29.940 --> 00:10:33.982
If it's 0 it's false, if it's
anything else it's true, all right.

178
00:10:33.982 --> 00:10:39.399
And just to show you that if I say abc,
then that is true.

179
00:10:39.399 --> 00:10:44.283
Now, I show you that because as we
continue on you need to keep this in

180
00:10:44.283 --> 00:10:49.087
mind because just to reiterate,
if you don't call this sometimes

181
00:10:49.087 --> 00:10:53.926
Python will actually call this on
your behalf in certain context.

182
00:10:53.926 --> 00:10:58.907
And will say well abc that's kinda like
true so we're gonna assume that it is,

183
00:10:58.907 --> 00:11:03.909
so you have to be careful cuz it will make
your program run a little bit differently.

184
00:11:03.909 --> 00:11:05.410
I'll say that upfront, but

185
00:11:05.410 --> 00:11:08.798
I'll also repeat that when we
actually come those situations.

186
00:11:08.798 --> 00:11:14.853
So, you can use bool to now get
a boolean representation of more or

187
00:11:14.853 --> 00:11:17.400
less any entity in Python.

188
00:11:17.400 --> 00:11:22.845
Now, we've seen some helps and

00:25:06.640 --> 00:25:09.550
Greater than or greater than or
equal to would also work with strings.

450
00:25:11.340 --> 00:25:13.630
But notice the context is
a little bit different.

451
00:25:13.630 --> 00:25:15.389
Does it come before that in the alphabet?

452
00:25:15.389 --> 00:25:21.100
There are some things that we have to,
is a less than capital a?

453
00:25:22.130 --> 00:25:23.980
Excuse me, let's do equals.

454
00:25:23.980 --> 00:25:27.100
Is a equal to capital A?

455
00:25:27.100 --> 00:25:31.640
No, capitalization does matter in strings.

456
00:25:31.640 --> 00:25:40.373
Which means, is apple less than apple?

457
00:25:40.373 --> 00:25:41.860
No.

458
00:25:41.860 --> 00:25:46.470
Is lowercase apple greater
than uppercase Apple?

459
00:25:46.470 --> 00:25:47.610
Yes, and

460
00:25:47.610 --> 00:25:52.270
that has to do with how these respective
letters are assumed to be in order.

461
00:25:53.570 --> 00:25:55.600
It does not go lower case a, upper case A.

462
00:25:56.870 --> 00:25:59.680
It actually, if I'm not mistaken,
it starts with all the upper cases and

463
00:25:59.680 --> 00:26:01.630
then it goes through the lower cases.

464
00:26:01.630 --> 00:26:03.490
So just be aware of that.

465
00:26:04.510 --> 00:26:05.990
So I show you that, right?

466
00:26:05.990 --> 00:26:08.200
We've compared the same
data types all the time.

467
00:26:08.200 --> 00:26:09.130
Number to number.

468
00:26:09.130 --> 00:26:11.787
And just to show you,
I can say is 3 equal to 3.2?

469
00:26:11.787 --> 00:26:14.430
That will work because
they're both numbers.

470
00:26:14.430 --> 00:26:16.030
But what if I do something like this?

471
00:26:16.030 --> 00:26:19.814
What if I say is apple equal to 4?

472
00:26:22.548 --> 00:26:26.510
And you could use this with
any other comparison operator.

473
00:26:26.510 --> 00:26:28.510
And no, it will not.

474
00:26:30.440 --> 00:26:33.010
That's not a meaningful comparison,
though, right?

475
00:26:33.010 --> 00:26:38.516
Is num_two == 'apple'?

476
00:26:38.516 --> 00:26:40.640
No, well, why not?

477
00:26:40.640 --> 00:26:42.450
Because that's the number two,
and that's apple.

478
00:26:44.710 --> 00:26:49.420
These can end up kind of being
real tough to chase down,

479
00:26:49.420 --> 00:26:54.370
real hard to reason about because maybe
something went wrong in your program and

480
00:26:54.370 --> 00:26:55.720
this ended up being the word apple.

481
00:26:56.990 --> 00:27:00.228
And you thought it was 6, the number 6.

482
00:27:00.228 --> 00:27:03.130
And you're like, well, yeah,
the number 2 doesn't equal the number 6.

483
00:27:03.130 --> 00:27:05.440
So that is false, that makes sense.

484
00:27:05.440 --> 00:27:09.170
But then other things start
breaking down the line.

485
00:27:09.170 --> 00:27:11.730
Now we're not seeing
that necessarily here.

486
00:27:11.730 --> 00:27:15.510
But you can compare a number to a string.

487
00:27:15.510 --> 00:27:18.480
You just may not get sensible results.

488
00:27:18.480 --> 00:27:20.150
You go, yeah, they're not equal.

489
00:27:20.150 --> 00:27:21.530
I guess that makes sense.

490
00:27:21.530 --> 00:27:24.040
Yeah, the word apple
is not the number two.

491
00:27:24.040 --> 00:27:25.430
So just be aware of that.

492
00:27:25.430 --> 00:27:30.652
Now, there is something that you may
encounter in some of these other

493
00:27:30.652 --> 00:27:36.613
languages, num_two, which is actually
a numeric type, it's an integer.

494
00:27:36.613 --> 00:27:40.460
This is a string containing a number.

495
00:27:41.570 --> 00:27:43.280
Are these two things equal?

496
00:27:44.550 --> 00:27:45.673
They are not.

497
00:27:45.673 --> 00:27:50.820
You have to be careful
because the type does matter.

498
00:27:50.820 --> 00:27:53.980
And a lot of times that
the types do not match,

499
00:27:53.980 --> 00:27:56.520
then they are automatically not equal.

500
00:27:56.520 --> 00:28:01.960
So you have to be careful on that sense.
>> Because I'm just saying two is two.

501
00:28:01.960 --> 00:28:06.430
I'm not paying attention to the little
quotes to indicate a string.

502
00:28:06.430 --> 00:28:09.664
And just as you said like,
comparing a number [INAUDIBLE],

503
00:28:09.664 --> 00:28:11.326
it's always gonna be false.

504
00:28:11.326 --> 00:28:13.334
So that's why you're saying it's okay,

505
00:28:13.334 --> 00:28:15.916
it might make sense in
whatever you're programming.

506
00:28:15.916 --> 00:28:18.920
But then once you get to that
where it needs to be true,

507
00:28:18.920 --> 00:28:20.310
it's never gonna be true.

508
00:28:20.310 --> 00:28:24.390
So that's where your results are gonna
get a little weird sometimes.

509
00:28:24.390 --> 00:28:26.310
>> You're absolutely right, and

510
00:28:26.310 --> 00:28:29.820
just be aware of these because notice,
this isn't throwing an error message.

511
00:28:29.820 --> 00:28:33.110
I try to show you the error
messages that you may encounter.

512
00:28:33.110 --> 00:28:38.960
These are known as runtime errors or
logic errors because they'll crop up and

513
00:28:38.960 --> 00:28:41.870
not exactly break where this breaks down.

514
00:28:41.870 --> 00:28:43.930
So you have to be careful there.

515
00:28:43.930 --> 00:28:46.662
And it's just part of
learning the program.

516
00:28:46.662 --> 00:28:51.072
Now, Vonne, these work for
strings and numbers.

517
00:28:51.072 --> 00:28:54.032
Equal will work for

518
00:28:54.032 --> 00:28:59.750
booleans as false equal to false.

519
00:28:59.750 --> 00:29:00.880
Yes, it is.

520
00:29:00.880 --> 00:29:01.980
These will also work there.

521
00:29:03.480 --> 00:29:04.790
You have to be careful, and

522
00:29:04.790 --> 00:29:08.990
I'll highlight this, as you get
kind of to more complex data types.

523
00:29:08.990 --> 00:29:11.510
Sometimes this will break down.

524
00:29:11.510 --> 00:29:15.690
It will not necessarily work
how you anticipate it to.

525
00:29:15.690 --> 00:29:18.610
Just like these will not work
how you anticipate it to.

526
00:29:18.610 --> 00:29:20.640
But these same operators are used.

527
00:29:20.640 --> 00:29:23.810
You just have to remember,
they're context specific.

528
00:29:23.810 --> 00:29:26.410
So always keep in mind,
what is the type of data?

529
00:29:26.410 --> 00:29:27.860
What is the value of the data?

530
00:29:27.860 --> 00:29:31.770
And does it make sense to have
these respective comparisons?

531
00:29:31.770 --> 00:29:34.490
If you keep that in the forefront of your
mind, it will save you a lot of time.

532
00:29:34.490 --> 00:29:36.280
But don't worry,
you're just getting started.

533
00:29:36.280 --> 00:29:39.306
So we've seen in this episode how
we can do less than, greater than,

534
00:29:39.306 --> 00:29:42.435
greater than or equal to, less than or
equal to, not equal and equal for

535
00:29:42.435 --> 00:29:45.222
both numbers and strings, and
technically booleans as well.

536
00:29:45.222 --> 00:29:49.230
We'll continue to see these
crop up as we need more.

537
00:29:49.230 --> 00:29:51.480
You're asking a yes or no question.

538
00:29:51.480 --> 00:29:53.040
Is this less than this?

539
00:29:53.040 --> 00:29:54.940
You're always gonna get a boolean answer.

540
00:29:54.940 --> 00:29:59.300
And now we can use that to start
actually building more complex logic.

541
00:30:00.450 --> 00:30:04.010
But there's a few more things that we need
to understand, and I don't think we have

542
00:30:04.010 --> 00:30:06.625
time in this episode.
>> All right, well,

543
00:30:06.625 --> 00:30:11.848
a little bit of comparison and also
some fact checking less infographical,

544
00:30:11.848 --> 00:30:14.230
lexicon, but lexicographical.

545
00:30:14.230 --> 00:30:16.060
I think we left out a C-O.

546
00:30:16.060 --> 00:30:18.080
Lexicographical.

547
00:30:18.080 --> 00:30:20.424
So that was one thing that I found.

548
00:30:20.424 --> 00:30:24.800
And that greater than or
equal to in Unicode, it is U2265.

549
00:30:24.800 --> 00:30:26.210
That's the character code.

550
00:30:26.210 --> 00:30:28.720
And remember I threw out that,
I think it was 257.

551
00:30:28.720 --> 00:30:30.460
That is a character code.

552
00:30:30.460 --> 00:30:34.270
I was thinking ASCII because it
only goes up to a certain number.

553
00:30:34.270 --> 00:30:41.340
No, the 257 is the letter
a with a little line over it.

554
00:30:41.340 --> 00:30:45.905
That whole area of ASCII and Unicode
totally, it's a geek moment for me.

555
00:30:45.905 --> 00:30:46.472
>> [LAUGH]

556
00:30:46.472 --> 00:30:49.893
>> I love character sets and typography,

557
00:30:49.893 --> 00:30:52.906
and I just wanted to tell you that.

558
00:30:52.906 --> 00:30:55.005
[LAUGH]
>> So other than my mispronunciation,

559
00:30:55.005 --> 00:31:01.045
lexicographical is ordered by
the respect of alphabetical,

560
00:31:01.045 --> 00:31:03.477
right?
>> Also known as dictionary order,

561
00:31:03.477 --> 00:31:06.992
alphabetical order,
a lexicographical product, yes.

562
00:31:06.992 --> 00:31:08.240
>> Yeah, well, I'm from the south, so

563
00:31:08.240 --> 00:31:09.660
sometimes we leave out letters.

564
00:31:09.660 --> 00:31:12.210
So I'm gonna chalk that one up to there.

565
00:31:12.210 --> 00:31:14.760
But Vonne,
we are definitely running low on time so

566
00:31:14.760 --> 00:31:18.900
I'm gonna let you take it over from here.
>> Yeah, I'm the host of this episode.

567
00:31:18.900 --> 00:31:20.400
So yes, we're out of time.

568
00:31:20.400 --> 00:31:22.250
So come on back and learn some more.

569
00:31:22.250 --> 00:31:25.185
And signing off for
DEVProTV, I'm your host,

570
00:31:25.185 --> 00:31:26.495
Vonne Smith.
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

571
00:31:26.495 --> 00:31:27.048
>> We'll see you soon.

572
00:31:27.048 --> 00:31:35.375
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne discuss how you can use logic control to create "smart" programs. Justin helps build a model of thinking for applying logical controls to programming.
episodes.title: Logic Control
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.117 --> 00:00:17.365
Hello everyone and welcome back to
another exciting edition of DevProTV.

3
00:00:17.365 --> 00:00:18.425
I'm your host Vonne Smith,

4
00:00:18.425 --> 00:00:21.635
and we are back with more on our
programming fundamentals series.

5
00:00:21.635 --> 00:00:24.285
And in this episode we're gonna
be talking about logic control.

6
00:00:24.285 --> 00:00:28.435
And here to control our learning is Mr.
Justin Dennison, how are you?

7
00:00:28.435 --> 00:00:30.250
>> I'm doing fantastic Vonne,
how are you today?

8
00:00:30.250 --> 00:00:35.910
>> Doing pretty good, so this is just
introducing the whole idea of logic and

9
00:00:35.910 --> 00:00:42.540
how we have to control our brains
before we go too far out of the ether.

10
00:00:42.540 --> 00:00:43.310
>> Absolutely correct.

11
00:00:43.310 --> 00:00:46.410
And really,
it's about kind of formalizing or

12
00:00:46.410 --> 00:00:49.960
building a mental model of well,
how did our programs run?

13
00:00:49.960 --> 00:00:53.010
Up until this point, we've just kinda
been line, by line, by line, by line.

14
00:00:53.010 --> 00:00:55.450
And there's not a lot going on, right?

15
00:00:55.450 --> 00:00:57.610
It's just, do this,
do this, do this, do this,

16
00:00:57.610 --> 00:01:00.760
do this, there's no way to alter that.

17
00:01:00.760 --> 00:01:06.125
And then what we're talking about is using
logic to control the flow of our programs.

18
00:01:07.960 --> 00:01:09.770
There is some programmatic
aspects to that but

19
00:01:09.770 --> 00:01:12.350
really we have to think,
well what does this mean?

20
00:01:12.350 --> 00:01:13.640
Do I need this decision?

21
00:01:13.640 --> 00:01:15.180
Or where does this decision go?

22
00:01:15.180 --> 00:01:16.560
We're gonna keep it simple, but

23
00:01:16.560 --> 00:01:20.310
it's just to bring to light that you
need be thinking about these things.

24
00:01:20.310 --> 00:01:24.827
>> Okay, your keyword right there was
simple because I know when I do Excel and

25
00:01:24.827 --> 00:01:28.570
we do all of these functions,
it gets, the logic is not easy.

26
00:01:28.570 --> 00:01:31.677
You think just be logical,
don't be so emotional.

27
00:01:31.677 --> 00:01:33.650
When we're talking in the human world or
anything like that.

28
00:01:33.650 --> 00:01:38.990
But when you start talking with
logic logic, you can get down

29
00:01:38.990 --> 00:01:43.053
a rabbit hole, twist it around, and just
really just end up crying in a corner.

30
00:01:43.053 --> 00:01:46.683
It goes like I don't understand,
it's supposed to just be logic.

31
00:01:46.683 --> 00:01:49.495
>> [LAUGH] So, well,
it's funny that you say that.

32
00:01:49.495 --> 00:01:52.676
We're not gonna talk about formal logic,
[NOISE] all right listen everybody.

33
00:01:52.676 --> 00:01:56.685
We're gonna talk about sets and operations
on sets, no, that's not what we're doing.

34
00:01:56.685 --> 00:02:02.440
But instead,
thinking about visualizing how a program

35
00:02:02.440 --> 00:02:07.640
flows and how that affects
what's going on, all right?

36
00:02:07.640 --> 00:02:10.790
So, that's our ultimate, we're not
gonna talk about programming now.

37
00:02:10.790 --> 00:02:15.390
We're gonna be talking about just kind
of everyday, essentially decisions

38
00:02:15.390 --> 00:02:19.630
that you make, but you need to make
sure you're formalizing those,

39
00:02:19.630 --> 00:02:22.380
building those into very
discrete kind of blocks.

40
00:02:22.380 --> 00:02:25.020
>> Okay, so
the thought process behind all this.

41
00:02:25.020 --> 00:02:29.645
Okay, that's made me feel a little bit
better because I was like we start getting

42
00:02:29.645 --> 00:02:33.450
into nots and they're opposites and
I'm like wait, which way is up?

43
00:02:33.450 --> 00:02:37.500
So I think I'm on board with this,
so we're good.

44
00:02:37.500 --> 00:02:39.663
>> All right, so we're gonna try our best.

45
00:02:39.663 --> 00:02:43.459
Let's think about,
we're just gonna draw some diagrams and

46
00:02:43.459 --> 00:02:48.278
we're gonna keep them kind of very high
level about how our programs currently

47
00:02:48.278 --> 00:02:50.485
run, right, up until this point.

48
00:02:50.485 --> 00:02:54.696
But then let's take a process and
formalize it, more or less,

49
00:02:54.696 --> 00:02:59.230
you could call this a mind map or
a flow chart or something like that.

50
00:02:59.230 --> 00:03:00.900
People are like, I don't like drawing.

51
00:03:00.900 --> 00:03:03.670
It's very, very important to
help you kind of build and

52
00:03:03.670 --> 00:03:08.850
understand, and it helps put down on
paper how your mind is thinking about it.

53
00:03:08.850 --> 00:03:14.130
And a good test is if you do this,
and you hand it to someone else and

54
00:03:14.130 --> 00:03:16.990
they go, what does this do?

55
00:03:16.990 --> 00:03:22.010
If you have to do a great
deal of explanation, okay,

56
00:03:22.010 --> 00:03:25.518
there is one possibility, that you didn't
preface what you were handing to him.

57
00:03:25.518 --> 00:03:27.500
You just kinda handed it to him like,
what do think of that?

58
00:03:27.500 --> 00:03:29.249
And they go, I don't know what that is.

59
00:03:30.320 --> 00:03:33.532
Or there's some things that
make sense to you, but

60
00:03:33.532 --> 00:03:37.717
you maybe you either haven't
provided explicit explanation, or

61
00:03:37.717 --> 00:03:40.720
sometimes we're just
a little bit different.

62
00:03:40.720 --> 00:03:45.575
I know that Vonne and I, we have different
perspectives on the exact same topic.

63
00:03:45.575 --> 00:03:50.149
So I think that adds to our team work,
but sometimes you just go,

64
00:03:50.149 --> 00:03:54.321
that's not how I thought about it but
that is a good point.

65
00:03:54.321 --> 00:03:59.123
So, those are very useful if you
just kinda draw on that map.

66
00:03:59.123 --> 00:04:00.884
Now, let's thing about
a program in general.

67
00:04:00.884 --> 00:04:02.813
And if we come down here and

68
00:04:02.813 --> 00:04:07.730
look at the iPad here,
let's look at where we are now, all right?

69
00:04:07.730 --> 00:04:10.510
So what do our program look like now?

70
00:04:10.510 --> 00:04:15.960
So I'm gonna ink to shape just so
we can get somewhat decent shapes here.

71
00:04:15.960 --> 00:04:20.527
And, so it's like, let's create a box and
what are we doing here?

72
00:04:20.527 --> 00:04:23.354
Well we're defining a variable, right?

73
00:04:23.354 --> 00:04:26.829
So that's line number one, so
you can think about it as line number one.

74
00:04:26.829 --> 00:04:32.631
So create a variable and
then what else are we doing?

75
00:04:32.631 --> 00:04:37.775
Well, we're adding 3 to that variable.

76
00:04:37.775 --> 00:04:41.880
I'm keeping this very simple so
we can fill in the blanks.

77
00:04:41.880 --> 00:04:43.389
And what are we doing next?

78
00:04:43.389 --> 00:04:50.096
Well, you're printing the variable out,
right?

79
00:04:50.096 --> 00:04:55.086
And to some extent,
that's all we've done thus far, right?

80
00:04:55.086 --> 00:05:01.070
Well, a lot of times you're like well,
I only wanna add 3 even if it is a number.

81
00:05:02.440 --> 00:05:07.070
If it's a string, I don't wanna add 3,
to it cuz then that's different.

82
00:05:07.070 --> 00:05:10.640
Or what if it's a boolean?

83
00:05:10.640 --> 00:05:13.360
If I add 3,
then I'm gonna get weird results,

84
00:05:13.360 --> 00:05:15.260
I should probably be able to look at that.

85
00:05:15.260 --> 00:05:23.960
I need to be able to inspect, think about,
react is kind of not the best word there.

86
00:05:23.960 --> 00:05:25.870
But currently our programs look like this.

87
00:05:25.870 --> 00:05:30.614
Really, and we're just gonna go at very,
very high level here,

88
00:05:30.614 --> 00:05:35.035
I'm thinking our programs could
look something like this.

89
00:05:39.443 --> 00:05:41.815
Right?
So you kinda get down here.

90
00:05:43.891 --> 00:05:49.380
And whenever I put an X,
that's a termination point, okay?

91
00:05:49.380 --> 00:05:53.120
So, our programs aren't necessarily
top to bottom always linked.

92
00:05:53.120 --> 00:06:00.030
There needs to be branches or some ways
to kind of move off to the side, okay?

93
00:06:00.030 --> 00:06:03.930
So, let's talk about this
in a more discrete, or

94
00:06:03.930 --> 00:06:07.580
a more concrete manner,
discrete, not discrete.

95
00:06:07.580 --> 00:06:09.560
Discrete may be an appropriate
terminology, but

96
00:06:09.560 --> 00:06:14.020
let's think about the process
of ordering a pizza.

97
00:06:14.020 --> 00:06:16.924
Gotta turn that ink to shape off just for
a moment [LAUGH].

98
00:06:16.924 --> 00:06:20.240
>> My god, a bird over there,
[LAUGH] I thought we're talking about.

99
00:06:21.460 --> 00:06:25.920
>> So let's order a pizza, and
you can't write with the eraser.

100
00:06:25.920 --> 00:06:30.025
So, order a pizza, all right?

101
00:06:30.025 --> 00:06:34.290
And, right now,
let's just kind of list the steps, so

102
00:06:34.290 --> 00:06:35.870
Vonne I'm going to need your
help here a little bit.

103
00:06:35.870 --> 00:06:40.090
So, when I go to order a pizza,
what are the first steps that I take?

104
00:06:40.090 --> 00:06:42.330
Well, not necessarily I take,
but what do you take?

105

So, right now it's two.

And then I'm gonna kind of give you

The python3 ifs, our favorite number is
two, hello zero, it only prints zero.

Well that makes sense, right?

So if any number is greater

If this if never executes theres

But if I come back-

I'm sorry I didn't mean to jump in.

After the one, two,

And well okay, else not five,

this is kind of what I was driving home

If it hits this else That

00:17:07.600 --> 00:17:12.580
So, the only time it would get

00:17:15.130 --> 00:17:18.130

00:17:18.130 --> 00:17:21.970
So, if I come here and

00:17:21.970 --> 00:17:23.950
I just showed you.

00:17:23.950 --> 00:17:24.600

00:17:24.600 --> 00:17:26.260
Zero three not five.

00:17:26.260 --> 00:17:27.810

00:17:27.810 --> 00:17:29.570
So that means it hit this one.

00:17:29.570 --> 00:17:31.450
It hit this one.

00:17:31.450 --> 00:17:34.960

00:17:34.960 --> 00:17:35.490
Now look.

00:17:36.720 --> 00:17:39.150
It's favorite number

There's no way that if

00:17:41.930 --> 00:17:45.700
The only way it gets to here Is

00:17:45.700 --> 00:17:48.430
it's not greater than five, so

00:17:50.110 --> 00:17:55.390
And this is why I did a bunch of this,

00:17:55.390 --> 00:17:59.490
to show you if you continue to do

00:17:59.490 --> 00:18:02.860
You can actually have code that

00:18:19.870 --> 00:18:25.540
Unless you discover some new numbers

Is doubtful.

00:18:26.490 --> 00:18:30.450
So be careful about this indentation,
a lot of ifs and ifs and ifs and

00:18:30.450 --> 00:18:33.300
ifs, as such.

And brought up another good point.

00:18:35.700 --> 00:18:38.440
This else,
see how this else is with this if?

00:18:41.028 --> 00:18:42.785
Wait for it, that's not what I wanted.

00:18:49.330 --> 00:18:53.410

00:18:56.600 --> 00:18:58.370

00:19:05.325 --> 00:19:09.400

00:19:51.535 --> 00:19:54.330

if you notice how it's printing out five.

You probably meant for that if and

00:20:05.180 --> 00:20:09.460
But if you're typing and

00:20:09.460 --> 00:20:10.600
I don't get a syntax error.

It still runs, it just says, well run this

348
00:20:17.350 --> 00:20:24.750
Which is where we get zero note five, so
you get nondeterministic runtime behavior.

349
00:20:24.750 --> 00:20:30.050
And I could tell I think my job
what I hoped to show, is probably

00:20:30.050 --> 00:20:35.090
a little too by Vonnes phase but I wanted
to show ifs are incredibly powerful and

elses are as well but there is a couple
of hiccups that you're gonna land into,

Especially if you're just getting started.

So by and large, don't do this, and

I only want this if

Right?

Well Vonne,

we actually have another construct

But maybe I should let everyone kind

And then come back and

actually fix this using another construct.
>> Yeah, I need to simmer on this one for

a little bit, because it's just like
>> Whoa, I mean it's all logic but

I feel like I just logicked myself

I don't know how to get out of this.

[LAUGH] And it's really important on

Glad I've kind of gotten that,

And you're gonna show us a little bit
Better ways to do it in the next episode.

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne look at another addition of if statements that will allow for more than "either-or" logic.
episodes.title: If-Elif-Else Statements

Now, the reason I'm doing that is this
is actually going to get rid of this

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:13.010 --> 00:00:16.316
Hello, everyone, and welcome back to
another exciting edition of DEVProTV.

3
00:00:16.316 --> 00:00:20.669
I am your host Vonne Smith, and we are
coming back at you with part two in our

4
00:00:20.669 --> 00:00:23.284
programming fundamental series on lists.

5
00:00:23.284 --> 00:00:24.842
And here to help us again, is Mr.

6
00:00:24.842 --> 00:00:27.591
Justin Dennison, how are you?
>> I am doing fantastic Vonne,

7
00:00:27.591 --> 00:00:30.385
how are you?
>> I think I am still doing pretty okay.

8
00:00:30.385 --> 00:00:33.865
I am getting a little hungry
talking about pizza over here.

9
00:00:33.865 --> 00:00:36.701
[LAUGH] If you have not
checked out our part one,

10
00:00:36.701 --> 00:00:41.378
definitely do that because we started
talking about ingredients of pizza.

11
00:00:41.378 --> 00:00:44.200
And that's what we use as
an example of our list.

12
00:00:44.200 --> 00:00:47.718
So that's the only thing I'm
thinking about right now [LAUGH].

13
00:00:47.718 --> 00:00:52.250
And besides you were using big math terms
over there on our previous episode.

14
00:00:52.250 --> 00:00:56.674
But, you're here to talk about some more
terms and things to deal with lists,

15
00:00:56.674 --> 00:00:59.231
so where do we wanna start?
>> Well we left off

16
00:00:59.231 --> 00:01:03.090
with actually seeing that we
could do a plus with two lists.

17
00:01:03.090 --> 00:01:06.265
We can actually do multiply with
a number and a list as long as

18
00:01:06.265 --> 00:01:10.535
that number is an integer, all the other
operations don't really make sense.

19
00:01:10.535 --> 00:01:12.350
So, where do we go from here?

20
00:01:12.350 --> 00:01:15.170
What else can we do with lists?

21
00:01:15.170 --> 00:01:20.030
Well, I wonder, I got,
I have the ingredients, right?

22
00:01:20.030 --> 00:01:22.795
I have that list of ingredients and
I want,

23
00:01:22.795 --> 00:01:24.800
what's the second ingredient to pizza?

24
00:01:24.800 --> 00:01:30.821
I don't know, that's right,
programmatically, I wouldn't know.

25
00:01:30.821 --> 00:01:34.061
But with a list because they're ordered,

26
00:01:34.061 --> 00:01:39.820
I should be able to effectively
query against that idea, right?

27
00:01:39.820 --> 00:01:40.340
So let's go ahead and

28
00:01:40.340 --> 00:01:45.150
take a look at the screen here, and
let's get that second ingredient, okay?

29
00:01:45.150 --> 00:01:47.720
So I'm gonna, temporarily,
I'm gonna highlight this.

30
00:01:47.720 --> 00:01:53.600
Cmd/ and that's just gonna comment that
out, so it'll temporarily make it go away.

31
00:01:53.600 --> 00:01:56.579
I'm always gonna leave these just so
we have a reference of what the previous

32
00:01:57.690 --> 00:02:00.650
ingredients numbers in Word are,
all right?

33
00:02:00.650 --> 00:02:08.375
So from here, let's talk about
accessing elements and slicing.

34
00:02:08.375 --> 00:02:12.574
All right, now, oddly enough,
slicing is a technical Python term, and

35
00:02:12.574 --> 00:02:14.840
we're also talking about pizza.

36
00:02:14.840 --> 00:02:16.871
It's like it came together perfectly,
I don't know.

37
00:02:16.871 --> 00:02:19.360
So let's look at the second ingredient,
all right?

38
00:02:19.360 --> 00:02:25.120
So I'm gonna grab this and put it in,
well second ingredient as a variable.

39
00:02:25.120 --> 00:02:28.780
I'm gonna say ingredients, and
you go well I want number [2].

40
00:02:28.780 --> 00:02:30.480
So we're using a square bracket there.

41
00:02:30.480 --> 00:02:32.520
This is where sometimes it
gets confusing for people.

42
00:02:32.520 --> 00:02:34.508
They are like well wait a minute,
square brackets?

43
00:02:34.508 --> 00:02:38.087
Like you can make a list with
square brackets, yes, but

44
00:02:38.087 --> 00:02:42.066
you also access elements using
the square bracket notation.

45
00:02:42.066 --> 00:02:46.960
Square bracket, what position,
and then square bracket, right?

46
00:02:46.960 --> 00:02:49.810
This is actually very similar to strings.

47
00:02:49.810 --> 00:02:55.500
As a matter of fact, it's exactly
the same as strings, all right?

48
00:02:55.500 --> 00:02:58.360
So here's our second ingredient,
all right, good deal.

49
00:02:58.360 --> 00:02:59.865
Let's go ahead and print that out.

50
00:02:59.865 --> 00:03:03.000
So print(second_ingredient).

51
00:03:03.000 --> 00:03:07.550
And we're gonna hop over here, and
we're gonna clear out, python3 lists.

52
00:03:07.550 --> 00:03:14.899
And mushrooms,
that's not what I anticipated.

53
00:03:14.899 --> 00:03:17.878
And well, full disclosure,
if you watched the string episode,

54
00:03:17.878 --> 00:03:19.405
you kinda know where I'm going.

55
00:03:19.405 --> 00:03:24.200
But It's kind of odd, nonetheless.
>> I

56
00:03:24.200 --> 00:03:29.070
was remembering our episode here and
I'm like, and we talked about slicing, or

57
00:03:29.070 --> 00:03:31.320
slicers and slicing when we
talked about strings, as well.

58
00:03:31.320 --> 00:03:34.194
So I'm like,
this is all sounding very familiar to me.

59
00:03:34.194 --> 00:03:38.319
And even when you were referencing
in that first part of our list,

60
00:03:38.319 --> 00:03:42.220
you said it's like the first, I'm like.

61
00:03:42.220 --> 00:03:47.902
He's doing that whole like zero length
index number thing of string characters.

62
00:03:47.902 --> 00:03:51.262
Wow, that was a very technical way
of explaining what we were doing.

63
00:03:51.262 --> 00:03:51.948
[LAUGH]
>> Tell you what,

64
00:03:51.948 --> 00:03:53.468
couldn't have said it better myself.
>> [LAUGH]

65
00:03:53.468 --> 00:03:55.390
>> But what Vonne's actually saying,

66
00:03:55.390 --> 00:03:56.449
and you're right.

67
00:03:56.449 --> 00:04:00.930
Sometimes using the terminology is
difficult just to keep things kind of

68
00:04:00.930 --> 00:04:03.670
clear but without getting too technical.

69
00:04:03.670 --> 00:04:08.550
It's crazy, but what Vonne's
talking about is this is index 0,

70
00:04:08.550 --> 00:04:12.290
this is index 1.

71
00:04:12.290 --> 00:04:16.297
This is index 2,

72
00:04:16.297 --> 00:04:21.110
and this is index 3.

73
00:04:21.110 --> 00:04:24.850
Notice I have 0, 1, 2, 3,
that is the respective position.

74
00:04:24.850 --> 00:04:26.464
So when I ask for the second,

75
00:04:26.464 --> 00:04:30.102
it actually gave me the third
because it started counting at 0.

76
00:04:30.102 --> 00:04:32.350
So we have to be careful there.

77
00:04:32.350 --> 00:04:36.320
Because pretty much every collection that
you're gonna interact with in Python and

78
00:04:36.320 --> 00:04:38.490
various other places
are going to be 0 indexed.

79
00:04:38.490 --> 00:04:43.491
That's not always true, but for the most
part, it is going to be 0 indexed.

80
00:04:43.491 --> 00:04:49.510
Notice my index is up to 3, but
I have 4 things in this list.

81
00:04:49.510 --> 00:04:56.128
Well, just to kinda play off this,
it seems very similar to strings.

82
00:04:56.128 --> 00:05:01.880
Well, what of ingredients_length,
or number of ingredients?

83
00:05:01.880 --> 00:05:05.279
Actually, let's call this
number_of_ingredients.

84
00:05:06.959 --> 00:05:10.021
Then I can say len(ingredients), and

85
00:05:10.021 --> 00:05:14.520
this is very similar to
how it works with strings.

86
00:05:14.520 --> 00:05:20.170
And if we just print that out,
number_of_ingredients, and we rerun this.

87
00:05:21.900 --> 00:05:26.766
Then notice we have 4, and that's
because I have 4 total elements, but

88
00:05:26.766 --> 00:05:28.815
the last index is actually 3.

89
00:05:28.815 --> 00:05:35.440
If I try to change this to 4,
right, as the length.

90
00:05:35.440 --> 00:05:40.170
Then we're gonna get an index error,
list index out of range, all right?

91
00:05:40.170 --> 00:05:43.634
So, let's actually make this
legitimately the second ingredient.

92
00:05:43.634 --> 00:05:47.157
So that would be an index of 1,
because it would be 0 and then 1.

93
00:05:47.157 --> 00:05:50.918
And so we hand the second ingredient,
we have the number of ingredients, but,

94
00:05:50.918 --> 00:05:52.200
you know what?

95
00:05:52.200 --> 00:05:53.440
I'm thinking, I don't like onions.

96
00:05:54.440 --> 00:05:57.500
I really just want,
I want Justin's ingredients.

97
00:05:57.500 --> 00:06:01.640
So I want all those other ingredients,
except not the onions.

98
00:06:03.020 --> 00:06:06.767
So there's a couple of ways
that I could accomplish that.

99
00:06:06.767 --> 00:06:13.213
We can change the element,
we can delete the element or,

100
00:06:13.213 --> 00:06:18.060
we could slice up the element, all right?

101
00:06:18.060 --> 00:06:19.650
Now, I'm going to show
you a couple things.

102
00:06:19.650 --> 00:06:22.707
Let's change the element.

103
00:06:22.707 --> 00:06:25.024
All right, so ingredients, and

104
00:06:25.024 --> 00:06:29.340
this is one of those things where
it's gonna get a little odd.

105
00:06:29.340 --> 00:06:34.129
I know that mushrooms, or excuse me,
onions, is at the index of 3,

106
00:06:34.129 --> 00:06:36.290
which is the fourth position.

107
00:06:36.290 --> 00:06:40.270
And I'm going to change that to,
more cheese.

108
00:06:40.270 --> 00:06:42.685
Notice how I have this on the left side.

109
00:06:42.685 --> 00:06:46.889
I'm gonna show you this in strings
because strings don't allow this.

110
00:06:46.889 --> 00:06:50.890
This is specific to lists.

111
00:06:50.890 --> 00:06:54.910
I can access the element set
it equal to a new element.

112
00:06:55.990 --> 00:07:01.130
But notice I don't actually get a new
variable, I just have the old variable.

113
00:07:01.130 --> 00:07:07.210
I'm going to print out ingredients
like so, and here we go.

114
00:07:07.210 --> 00:07:13.020
And I'm gonna [SOUND], python3, that is
not what I wanted to do, python3 lists.

115
00:07:13.020 --> 00:07:15.810
And notice I have cheese,
pepperoni, mushrooms, onions.

116
00:07:15.810 --> 00:07:18.040
But here I have cheese, pepperoni,
mushrooms, more cheese.

117
00:07:18.040 --> 00:07:22.850
Those are the exact same variable name,
and it's not a reuse of a variable name.

118
00:07:22.850 --> 00:07:26.960
I've actually modified the list itself.

119
00:07:26.960 --> 00:07:30.730
I will never have onions in this
list again, unless I go back and

120
00:07:30.730 --> 00:07:32.460
change it back.

121
00:07:32.460 --> 00:07:39.300
This can be [SOUND] kind of odd to think
about, I've actually mutated the list.

122
00:07:39.300 --> 00:07:45.560
Lists are mutable, not silence,
but able to be mutated.

123
00:07:45.560 --> 00:07:49.630
By large, you can do this,
I wouldn't actually do this though,

124
00:07:49.630 --> 00:07:53.260
it makes a little hard to reason about,
at least early on.

125
00:07:53.260 --> 00:07:57.202
>> Okay, I got a slight?

126
00:07:57.202 --> 00:08:01.244
Can you switch back over?

127
00:08:01.244 --> 00:08:04.739
And at this line 29 and 30 of the editor,

128
00:08:04.739 --> 00:08:10.640
this says print ingredients, but
back up point, do you mind moving up?

129
00:08:10.640 --> 00:08:14.626
Okay, there on line 12,
it's print ingredients.

130
00:08:14.626 --> 00:08:18.495
So it's only, cuz it printed it
with onions the first time, and

131
00:08:18.495 --> 00:08:21.660
then it printed it with more
cheese the second time.

132
00:08:21.660 --> 00:08:23.534
Is it because of where
you are on the code?

133
00:08:23.534 --> 00:08:27.752
I changed it at this point and
any time going forward,

134
00:08:27.752 --> 00:08:32.273
not the ingredients that was
called upon the first time.

135
00:08:32.273 --> 00:08:35.174
The second time is different, but

136
00:08:35.174 --> 00:08:39.670
the first time still exists as onions?
>> Yeah, you're exactly correct.

137
00:08:39.670 --> 00:08:43.090
So, what happens is it kinda
runs from top to bottom, right?

138
00:08:43.090 --> 00:08:47.830
So that first ingredients that we see
here is actually how we defined it.

139
00:08:47.830 --> 00:08:50.330
It's with onions and everything, and

140
00:08:50.330 --> 00:08:54.160
as we keep going, we're just bopping
along, and then we say, you know what?

141
00:08:54.160 --> 00:08:56.324
I want to change ingredients,

142
00:08:56.324 --> 00:09:01.329
I want to change the element at index
3 to more cheese instead of onion.

143
00:09:01.329 --> 00:09:04.531
What happens is onion goes,
I'm not part of that list any more.

144
00:09:04.531 --> 00:09:06.003
>> At this point in the code.

145
00:09:06.003 --> 00:09:08.327
>> This exact point in time,

146
00:09:08.327 --> 00:09:11.714
from here on out it will not be onions.

147
00:09:11.714 --> 00:09:15.856
But up until this point, up until line 29,

148
00:09:15.856 --> 00:09:19.570
ingredients was still had onions in it.

149
00:09:21.370 --> 00:09:25.960
And what we're discussing right now is
exactly the reason I think that mutation

150
00:09:25.960 --> 00:09:29.300
of lists make things weird for people.

151
00:09:29.300 --> 00:09:32.340
All right, so you're like, what is it?

152
00:09:32.340 --> 00:09:33.400
I changed something.

153
00:09:33.400 --> 00:09:34.370
When did it change?

154
00:09:34.370 --> 00:09:35.230
Where did it change?

155
00:09:35.230 --> 00:09:36.040
How did it change?

156
00:09:36.040 --> 00:09:36.560
Who changed it?

157
00:09:36.560 --> 00:09:40.495
There's so many questions that come
up by changing it like this that when

158
00:09:40.495 --> 00:09:44.567
you're first starting out, I would
probably not make changes like this.

159
00:09:44.567 --> 00:09:46.845
>> Yeah, cuz at first I'm like okay,

160
00:09:46.845 --> 00:09:50.340
that's kinda cool in the sense
of you could change on the fly.

161
00:09:50.340 --> 00:09:55.090
It has that flexibility, cuz maybe in

162
00:09:55.090 --> 00:09:59.980
some strange kind of outlier case of I get
to this point, but at the end of the game,

163
00:09:59.980 --> 00:10:03.880
I just wanna change this one, just for
this one time, but never again.

164
00:10:03.880 --> 00:10:08.522
I'll go ahead and
modify that particular list.

165
00:10:08.522 --> 00:10:13.083
But, like you're saying, now you're
putting it somewhere that's so deep in it

166
00:10:13.083 --> 00:10:17.850
that it might get kind of confusing,
of like, I don't understand this.

167
00:10:17.850 --> 00:10:21.410
I'm also putting it to like inline style
sheets versus global style sheets.

168
00:10:21.410 --> 00:10:23.320
And that will wreck your day.

169
00:10:23.320 --> 00:10:24.934
Why is this not working?

170
00:10:24.934 --> 00:10:29.560
There's some weird thing that's
attached to it that's overriding it.

171
00:10:29.560 --> 00:10:33.690
But I really want it to
apply at the global level.

172
00:10:33.690 --> 00:10:35.249
So that's what I'm thinking of.

173
00:10:35.249 --> 00:10:36.255
It's like yeah!

174
00:10:36.255 --> 00:10:37.633
Mm, I don't know about that one.

175
00:10:37.633 --> 00:10:40.016
[LAUGH]
>> It's worse when you're working with

176
00:10:40.016 --> 00:10:43.010
people and they make a change somewhere
in the code base that's very large.

177
00:10:43.010 --> 00:10:43.994
And then you don't know about it.

178
00:10:43.994 --> 00:10:45.564
And then you're like, wait a minute,

179
00:10:45.564 --> 00:10:48.130
there used to be onions in
this list of ingredients.

180
00:10:48.130 --> 00:10:50.574
And if you've ever got your
order wrong from a pizza joint,

181
00:10:50.574 --> 00:10:52.240
you know this is bad, right?

182
00:10:52.240 --> 00:10:53.734
You anticipated onions, there's no onions.

183
00:10:53.734 --> 00:10:55.250
Maybe you wanted onions and
there wasn't, it's bad.

184
00:10:55.250 --> 00:10:59.350
You can do this and it's perfectly okay.

185
00:11:00.380 --> 00:11:04.930
I would probably stay away from it at
least initially because you're gonna go,

186
00:11:04.930 --> 00:11:06.100
I don't know.

187
00:11:06.100 --> 00:11:09.890
I'm having trouble understanding
what's going on with my list.

188
00:11:09.890 --> 00:11:11.000
>> And just like you said,

189
00:11:11.000 --> 00:11:15.790
just because you can do it
doesn't mean you should do it.

190
00:11:15.790 --> 00:11:18.790
And don't get in a habit of it,
because later down the road,

191
00:11:18.790 --> 00:11:23.220
it will wreck your day, and
probably somebody else's day.

192
00:11:23.220 --> 00:11:30.438
Because it's also maybe that's the kind of
conformity, or the you shouldn't do this,

193
00:11:30.438 --> 00:11:36.712
we highly suggest you don't do it this
way in this coding, just don't do it.

194
00:11:36.712 --> 00:11:38.136
[LAUGH]
>> And to some extent,

195
00:11:38.136 --> 00:11:41.118
full disclosure, this is a little
bit of a personal bias of mine,

196
00:11:41.118 --> 00:11:44.060
I found that mutation makes things
really hard to reason about.

197
00:11:45.520 --> 00:11:48.060
If you're perfectly okay
with reasoning about it.

198
00:11:48.060 --> 00:11:49.750
Totally, do it, right?

199
00:11:49.750 --> 00:11:53.440
Your team may do it, if you're
working on a team, you may have to.

200
00:11:53.440 --> 00:11:57.580
But it already exists, but when you're
first starting out, if you can avoid it,

201
00:11:57.580 --> 00:12:01.584
try to avoid it.
>> Okay, and I'm gonna full disclosure,

202
00:12:01.584 --> 00:12:06.486
in the last episode when you said
mutable or I was like, silence,

203
00:12:06.486 --> 00:12:09.238
when you said no, it's not silence.

204
00:12:09.238 --> 00:12:14.094
That's because between the episodes like,
you mean mutate, I thought you meant

205
00:12:14.094 --> 00:12:18.100
like making it silent or hushing it or
making it go away for a little bit.

206
00:12:18.100 --> 00:12:19.705
No, you were talking
about changing the lists.

207
00:12:19.705 --> 00:12:23.700
So in case anybody else cought that,
or didn't catch that.

208
00:12:24.980 --> 00:12:25.700
I didn't get it.

209
00:12:25.700 --> 00:12:27.525
[LAUGH]
>> Well, that's all right,

210
00:12:27.525 --> 00:12:31.187
because context does make a huge
difference when you're using words that

211
00:12:31.187 --> 00:12:33.444
are spelled the same and
sound very similar.

212
00:12:33.444 --> 00:12:37.731
Along those same lines with changing
this though, I'm gonna comment this out,

213
00:12:37.731 --> 00:12:39.820
I don't want that to happen.

214
00:12:39.820 --> 00:12:45.370
But I am gonna do something
del ingredients[3].

215
00:12:45.370 --> 00:12:46.460
Notice that it turns purple.

216
00:12:48.610 --> 00:12:49.897
This actually says delete.

217
00:12:49.897 --> 00:12:53.490
Delete this thing, all right?

218
00:12:53.490 --> 00:12:55.760
Let's go back, let's rerun it.

219
00:12:55.760 --> 00:12:59.030
You actually have to type
stuff appropriately, and

220
00:12:59.030 --> 00:13:01.170
notice onions is no longer there.

221
00:13:01.170 --> 00:13:02.470
I've deleted that element.

222
00:13:03.750 --> 00:13:07.193
I would argue this is very
similar to reassigning it.

223
00:13:07.193 --> 00:13:09.980
It has changed the original list.

224
00:13:09.980 --> 00:13:13.600
Again, along the same lines,
don't necessarily do this.

225
00:13:13.600 --> 00:13:18.781
What I would suggest is instead of
changing ingredients, is create

226
00:13:18.781 --> 00:13:24.580
justin_ingredients, where we
want just a part of those.

227

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne take a look at dictionaries that provide yet a different way to arranging data. Justin discusses when to use lists and tuples versus dictionaries as well as provides an overview of operations that you can use with dictionaries.
episodes.title: Dictionaries

47

In Python dictionaries, for every key

55

But the global environment is more or

So behind the scenes dictionaries

Now why would I not just define
a bunch of variables like first name,

those types of things and just have them.

Well, the reason that I would want to do
this is I want to bind all of those things

84
00:04:24.730 --> 00:04:32.190
A first name, last name, favorite food,
pizza, age- Yeah pizza defines us all.

85
00:04:32.190 --> 00:04:34.910
Those all define a person or
possibly a user.

86
00:04:36.100 --> 00:04:40.160
So those are bundled together so it's
a way of taking essentially variables.

87
00:04:40.160 --> 00:04:44.305
But bundling them up so
they track along together.

88
00:04:44.305 --> 00:04:46.290
Tied them together so that it makes sense.

89
00:04:46.290 --> 00:04:52.490
And at the abstract level this dictionary
represents a more, kind of unified entity.

90
00:04:52.490 --> 00:04:55.860
Now, that's a whole lot of

I think it's important to see,
how do we make dictionaries,

when do we use dictionaries?

And I do want to talk about

So there's a little added extra for

So definitely stay tuned.

But let's go ahead and

And we have a terminal window and

I'm inside of my programming

That's good.

We have ifs lists, and then tuples.

Correspondingly I have my visual

So let's hop back over here and

Just so we can so touch dictionaries.py.

I think I spelled dictionaries, right?

Yep, I did, I'm pretty sure I did.

So let's say I have a user, right.

Pair.

And what's interesting is this pairing,

00:08:33.250 --> 00:08:35.990

00:08:35.990 --> 00:08:38.570

00:08:38.570 --> 00:08:39.850

00:08:39.850 --> 00:08:41.460
Now why would I wanna

00:08:41.460 --> 00:08:43.850
I could just make it first name,

00:08:43.850 --> 00:08:48.720

00:08:48.720 --> 00:08:53.200

00:08:53.200 --> 00:08:56.310
So these are mostly strings.

Most of the time you're gonna

There are some requirements for the keys.

Strings meet those requirements.

165
00:09:07.910 --> 00:09:11.990
Other things that meet those

00:09:11.990 --> 00:09:16.260
you can do something like this,
like, zero, colon, pizza

167
00:09:17.344 --> 00:09:22.770
1: 'cookie' } and we'll leave it there.

168
00:09:22.770 --> 00:09:26.230
Adding more won't actually change things.

169
00:09:26.230 --> 00:09:28.650
I can use numbers as the keys.

170
00:09:28.650 --> 00:09:31.620
It's interesting,
if you use numbers as the keys,

171
00:09:31.620 --> 00:09:37.060
you end up with what appears to be
a list but it's not actually a list.

172
00:09:38.290 --> 00:09:40.190
How we use it though
will look like a list.

173
00:09:40.190 --> 00:09:45.320
So numbers I tend to stay away from,
this doesn't have a lot of meaning

174
00:09:45.320 --> 00:09:49.790
to me in a more semantic fashion.
>> Yeah, that's weird.

175
00:09:49.790 --> 00:09:50.565
I'll just say that right now.

176
00:09:50.565 --> 00:09:53.685
I'm over here going, what?

177
00:09:53.685 --> 00:09:55.515
So zero is pizza?

178
00:09:55.515 --> 00:09:58.135
One, it doesn't make any logical sense.

179
00:09:58.135 --> 00:10:02.815
I just feel like that can get
you really confused really fast.

180
00:10:02.815 --> 00:10:06.583
I feels there's obviously different things
we're going to be able to do within these

181
00:10:06.583 --> 00:10:07.328
dictionaries.

182
00:10:07.328 --> 00:10:11.991
So is this one of those you can do it but

183
00:10:11.991 --> 00:10:14.370
don't?
>> I wouldn't say don't.

184
00:10:14.370 --> 00:10:17.880
There are very particular use
cases because dictionaries,

185
00:10:19.000 --> 00:10:21.150
they have really fast look ups.

186
00:10:21.150 --> 00:10:26.220
What I mean is, if I want
the zeroth key behind the scenes,

187
00:10:26.220 --> 00:10:31.340
that look up finding that zero is
pizza Is going to be very, very fast.

188
00:10:31.340 --> 00:10:32.740
Now, with that said,

189
00:10:32.740 --> 00:10:36.410
if I'm looking at the zeroth element
of the list that's also pretty fast.

190
00:10:36.410 --> 00:10:40.700
But, as you get deeper into python
you'll find that there are some

191
00:10:40.700 --> 00:10:42.470
things that dictionaries
are better suited for.

192
00:10:42.470 --> 00:10:46.980
And some things that lists
are better suited for.

193
00:10:46.980 --> 00:10:50.505

And on items, call will always give you

So, I don't need this,

I can use just the value,

I can use just the key.

I don't really have to

I just call .items or t,
value in foods.items, boom.

originally.

But now,
you'll see this a lot in Pythonic code.

00:26:34.182 --> 00:26:37.140
Tuple Unpacking is what
makes this possible.

430
00:26:37.140 --> 00:26:39.521
>> To me,
it's just like you're adding a hetero.

00:26:39.521 --> 00:26:44.528
You're actually claiming it in a really,

00:26:44.528 --> 00:26:49.380
a very slick way of doing it,
like, okay, well, there you go.

Now That makes total sense.

434
00:26:51.400 --> 00:26:54.755
>> It does make sense, it takes
a little while to read through it, so

435

be careful there.

You can get into trouble

437
00:26:58.010 --> 00:27:00.471
List will actually let you

00:27:00.471 --> 00:27:02.692
So, if I have a list of two elements,

I could assign variables to

I write Python code like this, but

I needed it kinda let it sink in, and

We've talked about this, like,

Just because, it would actually cloud the,

It's like I don't want to

So, I appreciate it, thank you.

>> Well, hopefully it all works out,

because this construct

Because there are other things

Now quick reminder, tuples and

An alternative to that,

Sets, they don't have an order,

you only get to use the Pythonic for

Dictionaries, you get keys,

You keep that in mind, that construct

It makes your code a lot cleaner.

I argue it makes it more readable.

But I did keep it from you how

But, we'll see more of it, and

that, that it does make things clean and

Just take some getting used to them.

00:29:08.325 --> 00:29:09.678

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne discuss a different loop, the while loop. Justin explores some of the differences as well as highlights some other uses for the while loop.
episodes.title: While Loops

I'm actually gonna show you,

pretty much anything you

There's one other use case, more or

loop, you can do with the while

And that's if you intentionally

I wanna loop forever and you're going,

Cool, I'm gonna do this.

Come back around,

Cool, I'm gonna do this.

So that is the one kind of edge case.

Now it's, I typically don't

Like or instance, I wanna grab

then I wanna do something with that.
>> Sorry, quick question.

So with the four loop, okay, for
however many there are, just keep going.

00:02:17.571 --> 00:02:20.970
So there was like one, two, three,
four, five, and then it stopped.

00:02:20.970 --> 00:02:23.700
The while,
as soon as you call the while loop,

it's just gonna keep going
until you tell it to stop?

Is keep going until I say

Is that how like the fundamental
difference is between for

and while loops?

00:02:38.727 --> 00:02:42.620
for is some number for,
some number of times.

A while is, while something is true,

So that's kind of our condition.

If you don't know how long

If you're like,

Can you use one where the other?.

Yeah, except for

So what I mean is, can I iterate over

I sure can and that's actually we're

a four loop that we saw

kinda use that to jump into

But as I said, I use a while loop

So let's go ahead and take a look at the
screen here and I have the same programing

Let's open it up, and let's close

Now, let's look at numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.

Now, if you had a tuple this would work,

If you had a set, or

You have to have some way to

So this only works for

But a for loop and a while loop

So, if we wanted to print out

Numbers, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.

How would I do that with a for loop.

Well, I'm gonna say for

Okay.

There was also an alternative way.

Where, instead of that it was

we can say for the index in the range

And let's start at 0,

85
00:05:10.297 --> 00:05:15.127
we're gonna start at 0 because I do

00:05:15.127 --> 00:05:19.612
And I could say print, or excuse me,

element equals numbers for the index and

Excuse me, not the index,

There we go, so there's our element.

But now,

So, while something is true,

102
00:06:06.950 --> 00:06:09.328
So let's see here.

00:06:09.328 --> 00:06:13.920
I'm going to

00:06:13.920 --> 00:06:18.900

So the index where do I want to start?

I want to start at the first

Now, I'm just doing that.

Just storing it in a variable so you can

00:06:43.501 --> 00:06:48.354
And now, I'm gonna say while,

113
00:06:48.354 --> 00:06:56.480
While the index is less

114
00:06:56.480 --> 00:07:02.073
So let's compare this for
the index in sum collection,

115
00:07:02.073 --> 00:07:06.601
this, is going to evaluate to true or
false.

00:07:06.601 --> 00:07:09.527
Is 0 less than, how many are in numbers?

00:07:09.527 --> 00:07:10.203
5.

00:07:10.203 --> 00:07:12.360
Yes, 0 is less than 5.

00:07:12.360 --> 00:07:16.610

As soon as it turns to false, stop.

Okay?

So it is a true or false.

You could almost think of it

00:07:26.450 --> 00:07:30.520
If this is true do this thing,

00:07:30.520 --> 00:07:35.858
Well a while is very similar except
when it reaches the bottom it doesn't

00:07:35.858 --> 00:07:40.772

00:07:40.772 --> 00:07:43.053
And does it again, okay?

128
00:07:43.053 --> 00:07:45.620
Now I'm gonna write it correctly and

00:07:46.650 --> 00:07:47.569
So what do I wanna do?

I wanna grab the element and

00:07:51.638 --> 00:07:55.451

here's the tricky part, You have to think,

00:08:01.417 --> 00:08:05.449
Well when it gets to the last number,

134
00:08:05.449 --> 00:08:07.730
When index is less than numbers length.

135
00:08:07.730 --> 00:08:10.260
Well index is zero,
numbers length is five.

136
00:08:11.490 --> 00:08:13.020
When is zero less than five?

137
00:08:13.020 --> 00:08:15.480
Always, it's always less than five.

138
00:08:16.620 --> 00:08:18.430
You have to modify.

139
00:08:20.260 --> 00:08:22.316
It can be by one, by two.

140
00:08:22.316 --> 00:08:29.280
I'm changing this value

00:08:29.280 --> 00:08:34.850

00:08:34.850 --> 00:08:38.640
If I don't then I end up

And you'll get weird behaviors.

That may be what you want

That's probably not what you want if

146
00:08:47.840 --> 00:08:51.430
So let's see if this works and
I could be wrong.

147
00:08:51.430 --> 00:08:55.020
This is the hiccup of while loop.

148
00:08:55.020 --> 00:08:58.760
Sometimes you still have
things that go wrong, and

149
00:08:58.760 --> 00:09:02.590
I'm gonna comment this out just so
we can make sure they were

150
00:09:02.590 --> 00:09:07.560
comparing what we think we are or
absorbing what we think we are.

151
00:09:07.560 --> 00:09:09.160
So one, two, three, four, five.

152
00:09:09.160 --> 00:09:13.800
We get the exact same output as
the four loop and we have a while loop.

153
00:09:13.800 --> 00:09:18.740
Now notice how I spend
a lot of time talking about

154
00:09:18.740 --> 00:09:22.110
this condition and this modification.

155
00:09:23.330 --> 00:09:27.360
I'm gonna show you what happens if oops,
I forgot to type that.

00:09:29.310 --> 00:09:32.230
You better have your trigger
finger ready because it's

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore creating lists using loops. However, Python provides an alternative to using standard for loops to populate new lists, the list comprehension. Justin demonstrates the use of list comprehensions as well as compares the readability of list comprehensions versus creating lists using standard for loops.

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne review how to create dictionaries as well as how to use list comprehensions to create dictionaries. Justin then extends the usage to dictionary comprehensions as well as provides a comparison of readability of dictionary comprehensions to others.
